channel.title: goodguysdofinishfirst.com
channel.description: it's more than just a gig...

wp:category.wp:category_description: Discussions involving experiential marketing and all of its moving parts.
Subjects that address the many "day in the life of". By giving our partners in success, the office, we can learn to effective communicate more effectively, that produces results.
Ever considered touring? Follow me on my 17-week tour. There's ups, downs, mechanical breakdowns and fireworks. Sit shotgun and learn about the real risks and rewards of mobile touring.
Insights and views that dive deeper into agency development and practices.
Bridging the gap between staff and the office, we examine, evaluate and share how agencies interact with independent contractors and vice versa.
Guide for those who are new to event marketing industry or have changed roles.
Straight from your favorite social media, topics and discussions circling feeds, updates, pins and tweets.
Covering good practices to avoid bad situations that could lead to ugly outcomes.

wp:term.wp:term_description: An account of details pertaining to accomplishments, endeavors and challenges away from the home market.

item.content:encoded: NES doesn't recommend using their own standard service....hmmm.

item.title: Life On The Road
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Like many folks in this industry, I started my career in event marketing as a brand ambassador. Shortly after discovering another opportunity within the field, mobile tours, getting on the road was my main focus and goal. That was almost ten years ago.
Since then, I've been privileged to have represented leading brands on some amazing programs. What has been the most rewarding aspect of my career on the road are the places I've gone, the things I've seen and undoubtedly the people I've met.
Life on the road is not without its challenges. It's not some type of paid vacation. There is work to be done. Problems to solve, both external and internal. Mental and physical. People and personalities. All in an effort to achieve one goal, a successful program. One seemingly flawless event execution at a time.
After taking a year off from hard-core mobile touring, I decided to come back to the road.
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/-HTkiiMlDwo?rel=0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>
 
Seasoned veteran or someone considering taking on the risks and rewards that this type of lifestyle brings. Join me on my journey as I take on my current tour with 5 other teammates for the next 4 months.
Of course names, companies, and brands will be changed or omitted for obvious reasons. But in exchange for doing so, you'll be riding shotgun with me. An inside look in true "Good Guy" fashion. No fluff. No BS. Never.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Life on the road. Join me as I go back to mobile marketing on a 17-week program. Ride shotgun with this "Good Guy" and peek into the reality of mobile tours

item.title: Hello, My Name Is... Life On The Road Week 1
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Week 1 is always an intriguing period of time on tour. Outside of the standard brand orientations and company policy briefings, here is where you meet the folks who hired you and your co-workers face to face for the first time. Looking back on the tours I've done, I often marvel at how relationships and dynamics change from the first week to the last week. My first week back on tour would only rekindle this curiosity. [su_carousel source="media: 1313,1311,1310,1309,120" link="lightbox" width="440" height="300" items="1" title="no" arrows="no"] I've been on tour with six other guys. I've been on the road with women. But I've never been on the road with both. For this program, a young guy/girl couple is heading up the tour. Two male and two female support managers. Everyone has a roommate. I'll speak on that later...lol. As with any new experience, I'm looking forward to learning about myself under this new backdrop. I'm also excited to learn about the people who will count on me and vice versa in accomplishing a successful tour. We all arrived at the airport at different times and in different dispositions. Some were very talkative while others were clearly worn from the day's travels. Most of the ride from the airport to hotel was spent sizing each other up. Myself included. [caption id="attachment_1315" align="aligncenter" width="441"] Ride to the Hotel.[/caption] Not only do I want to know what my new teammates are capable of as a skill set, I also want to know what type of personalities I'll be spending the next 17 weeks with on this mobile marketing tour.

Some chose the validation route. "Well, I've done this, this and this." Maybe to ensure our new bosses, each other and themselves that they were worthy of the opportunity and capable of the task ahead.

In most new introduction situations, I choose the "poker" approach. Offering up information in exchange for gaining even more valuable information. Tactfully offering up a mix of validation dialog, a flash of my character, followed up by fruit-bearing questions. How they answer is just as important as the answer themselves in these type of interactions. As cutthroat as it sounds, sizing each other up is not so dark. It's human nature. I want to know who I'm working with. Their skills and personalities. And rightfully so do my five other teammates. Watching it take place among 6 people is both an education in human behavior and entertaining. Doing so in a non-threatening way requires skill. It was clear early on that I wasn't the only person who knew how to play...

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In week 1 of my mobile marketing tour, we are introduced to our bosses and co-workers. Sizing up each others personalities and abilities is just the start.

item.title: My Tour Teammates
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Allow me to introduce you to my tour teammates. Written a couple of weeks into the program, I look forward to coming back to this page at the end of my experience. To see how the dynamics and relationships have changed through our 17 weeks together. What they reveal about my new teammates and about myself. Like onions, human beings have many layers. Nothing peels back the layers like work, living in close quarters, and tackling a goal littered with challenges and triumphs. Out of respect for my fellow teammates, I have changed their names. I have also generalized their ethnic and regional residence to protect their identities. What remains is an account of our interactions and experiences as told from my point of view. Let's meet the team. Lead Tour Managers   Jack & Dianne are a touring couple. and the lead tour managers for this program.At the end of the day, they are accountable to the home office for all activation operations in the field. Touring as a couple has its challenges and tests even the strongest of relationships. What time does work end and the personal time begin? And vice versa. Having completed several programs together, they’ve obviously found a balance and earned the trust of companies that seek their services. But this program presents a new set of challenges. They are faced with the task of managing four other team members. All with Alpha characteristics and lead tour management experience to back up their personas. Keeping us at bay while also giving us opportunities to contribute our collective vast knowledge is an aspect of managing this tour that I truly do not envy. Everyone on the team has touring experience on their resume. Well...except for one. A rookie to the road who will be introduced later. Jack is European, in his mid 30’s from the southeast region of the U.S. By all accounts, a seasoned and experienced veteran. I initially found Jack somewhat reserved. An introvert except when the situation requires more outward dialog. Picking and choosing his spots to assert his knowledge and leadership within the framework of the team. His personality and demeanor are complimentary to his significant other Dianne.

Dianne is a southern woman in her early  30’s with all the customary southern pleasantries one would expect from a traditional southern gal. She’s the ying to his yang. A complete extrovert. Dianne is a well educated and articulate individual and veteran of the road. A feat not easily accomplished in the male dominated side of our industry. Although she’s a southern girl, I sense that she knows how to shove back when the boys get rowdy. The art of successful women out here is knowing when to shove back and how hard to shove when it’s needed. In this, I’m eager to observe.

The Assistant Tour Managers Halle is one of the two female assistants on the team. Black and in her mid 20’s, she is also a well-educated team member from the south. Halle carries a wide mix of experience. She has a degree, some corporate “9-5” experience and touring under her belt. Still finding her place in the world and eager to enjoy all the independence and freedoms that come with having found one’s calling in life. I find her “wait & see” approach to her positioning amongst the other assistant managers intriguing. Her character and how she presents herself reverberates a tone of “things are not always what they seem.” Even though she has tour and lead manager experience, she is also one of the youngest in the pack.   Cathy is the other female assistant manager. Besides sharing a room with Halle, she also shares with her being the youngest in our group. But that’s where the similarities end. In her mid 20’s, Cathy is a Caucasian action-sports woman from the northwest. She is also the rookie on the team. I’m both happy and reluctant to have a rookie in the fold. Happy in the sense that we will all get to take advantage of witnessing touring all over again with a child-like wonder. Reluctant because we’ll collectively have to train our rookie in the art of mobile touring under sometimes less than favorable circumstances.   As I had mentioned in the introduction, challenges are not an “if” but a “when”. To the experienced, challenges and adversity are like morticians seeing a dead body. Yeah, they may be uniquely different looking, one thing remains the same. They need to be resolved and ceremoniously sent to the after-life. Let’s hope our rookie has a strong stomach. Larry is my roommate on this journey. Like myself, Larry lives on the west coast, is no stranger to the road, has tour lead experience, in his early 40’s and has aspirations and side projects related to but not always directly to the industry. This is the person that I will be spending the most time with over the next 17 weeks. When Larry wakes up, I’m the first face he sees. When I go to bed, his face is the last face I see.   Like the rest of the team, Larry and I will have to adjust to each other living in close quarters. We’ll have to be mindful of each other’s habits and rituals. Times we wake up. Times we shut it down. What happens when we come into our shared space and so on and so forth. The only difference is that Jack & Dianne have a bit more practice at it and get to know each other before being tossed in a room together. I have no complaints about the situation from the start. I was made well aware that I’d be sharing a room before I ever saw my contract. I've enjoyed some great friendships as a result of having a stranger as a roommate. My two closest friends on the planet met under these circumstances. But will my luck run out? I remain optimistic.

And hopefully by now, you all know me. If you are new to GoodGuysDoFinishFirst.com, and would like to know more, just follow this link "about me". If you’d like to reach stalker status, lol, you can read my complete profile and experience here.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Meet my tour teammates. Life on the road has its challenges. How will unique personalities and skills work together in producing a successful mobile tour.

item.title: 6 Becomes 5. Life On The Road. Week 2
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Week 2 of my 17 week kept within the script of the many other tours that I've been involved with,..for the most part. I have a love/hate relationship with the second week of mobile tours. I love executing what we have planned and practiced in training. Hate when the plan goes awry. Love when intelligent minds come together, set aside egos, and come up with a professional solution to an unforeseen issue.
The Kinks
If you're reading this as someone who is new to touring, there will be kinks to iron out. You can absolutely count on it.  When I was new to touring, these issues used to leave me scratching my head. At this point in my career, I understand that there is a solution to every problem. So all there is left to do is learn from the experience and enjoy the laugh that unexpected circumstances bring.

[su_animate type="slideInRight" delay="0.5"]Playground of Gremlins[/su_animate] [su_animate type="slideInRight" delay="1.0"]Equipment Failures[/su_animate] [su_animate type="slideInRight" delay="1.5"]Design Miscues[/su_animate] [su_animate type="slideInRight" delay="2.0"]Logistics Challenges[/su_animate] [su_animate type="slideInRight" delay="2.5"]Scheduling Conflicts[/su_animate] [su_animate type="slideInRight" delay="3.0"]Ordering/Deliverables Hiccups[/su_animate]

Our tour would have all five of these.

The veterans and our home office support team would remain calm, cool and confident.

Our rookie would freak.

Family Night
Also with any mobile tour program, the opportunity to step out of our roles and responsibilities to bond is customary. Our bonding moment, a night out at the movies. Nothing like a little Will Farrell & Kevin Hart to lighten the mood and disengage our constantly working minds. Movie night, like any "date", is a safe choice. Everyone gets to say that we spent time together, but there's not that much engagement. After the week we had, it was still the best choice. No pressure and it also provided an opportunity to forget about some of the challenges we had faced throughout the week. Besides, we would more than make up for this ultra safe pick later.
Family Night Part 2
Now that we've addressed some of our tour-related challenges, adjusted to our schedule and responsibilities, it was time to start peeling the onion that is our personalities. With our next day being an off day, a few bottles of wine and a trivia board game at our hotel provided a safe and fun setting to do so. [caption id="attachment_1355" align="alignleft" width="240"] Photo courtesy of Shanna Gillette
www.sasharaephoto.com[/caption] We learned much about each other during game & wine night. Not only did we learn about each others cultural differences and knowledge, we also got a glimpse of how well our personalities would translate into the working environment. The games we played required some level of cooperation. They also tested our abilities to communicate with one another. The wine provided some truth serum and relaxed our week one guards. It was a fun time. But would our evening together create a desire to spend more time or less time together? Only the future will tell.
Pack Your Bags. You're Going Home. A Rookie Mistake.
With a team of our size, the diverse backgrounds, and personalities, the odds of all 6 of us making it [caption id="attachment_1354" align="alignright" width="240"] Photo courtesy of Shanna Gillette
www.sasharaephoto.com[/caption] through the 17 weeks were unlikely. Although I would have bet the house on our rookie, I never thought it would've been in week 2. If you've read my posts on being fired, You're Fired! What's Next & You’re Fired! What’s Next? Navigating the Fallout. , you'd know that I can't and won't discuss the nature of our rookie's firing. However, what I will say is that I hope that she has learned something from her brief experience on the road. Not only about people in general but especially about herself and what it takes to be a successful professional in this industry. Her departure was met with mixed emotions throughout the team. Regardless of how we all felt about her departure, we were all now challenged to pick up the slack that her absence had now created.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In week 2 of my 17-week tour, our team faces the challenge of working out some beginning tour program kinks. But we also lose a team member. 6 becomes 5.

item.title: Super Powers Revealed. Life On The Road. Week 3.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: By week 3 of my 17-week tour, the kinks have been worked out and the program is running like a well-oiled machine. As a group and individually, we are aware of our work-related strengths and weaknesses. That type of discovery is critical to the success of any program. Sure, we'd all like to think that we are the ultimate team player. Highly skilled at every position. All five of us have the skills necessary to execute a successful strike. The reality is that there are skills and roles that we are good at. Skills that we are adequate at. Then there are skills that we excel at to the point that we make other professionals look like amateurs. To quote the movie The Longest Yard..."He makes people who are fast look not so fast." It's truly an awesome time that requires some flexing and humility. Individually, we have to concede that someone in our group is better at a particular skill than we are. We also get opportunities to display our mastery of our strengths in front of other professionals. Easier said than done. Remember, we are all Alpha dogs in our own right. This process seemed to have happened without too many egos being bruised. I feel that most of the team members grasp the Vidal Sassoon concept. "You don't look good. We don't look good." [caption id="attachment_1387" align="alignleft" width="372"] Jack brings it all together.[/caption] Jack's superpower is his ability to bring it all together. There are plenty of moving parts to our program. Pick-ups. Deliveries. Logistics. Scheduling. When he shares information regarding any aspect of the big picture of a particular activation, I have complete confidence in his words. I find his method of communicating extremely efficient and effective. Dianne's superpower is "showtime". There are many conversations and emails that happen before an event actually strikes. Conversations that we support managers are not involved in by design. But when it comes to "showtime", I marvel at Dianne's skills. She communicates to event contacts, talent coordinators and talent in a way that is similar to my own style. However,  when it comes to training our local brand ambassadors, I take notes. I thought I was pretty good at communicating the code of conduct expectations and brand messaging to local brand ambassadors. She blows me away. Our product and brand messaging caters to a very educated and potentially sensitive audience. After sitting in on one of her pre-event training sessions, I appreciated her ability to instill the brand's messaging to our local staff. I also admired her tactfulness in doing so. Now keep in mind Jack & Dianne are the lead tour managers on this program. They answer directly to the producing agency and brand. There are other functions I don't get to see their skills first hand because of my support role. What I do know is that we have executed flawless events as a result of their behind the scenes efforts. Halle is a Transformer. In addition to our tour experience, Halle and I were hired for our specific skill set required [caption id="attachment_1388" align="alignleft" width="396"] Whatever you need, Halle "Is".[/caption] by the brand's needs. When it comes to showtime, Halle and I have a very clear function and expertise based on our past training. What I admire about Halle is that no matter what the task is, she is more than capable. In attitude and ability. Whenever the program requires a little wiggle room, she is more than eager to oblige. When our program has faced adversity, she has been quick to offer solutions that could potentially affect her own well being. Her flexibility and self-sacrificing demeanor are refreshing. Because of our specific skill set, Halle and I often work in the same area of our event element. When we do, it's like a dance and I love it. We both understand the importance of the finished product. We are also both big picture people, committed to making the program successful and supporting Jack & Dianne in any way possible. When Halle and I work together, there are no egos. If I forget something, she kindly reminds me. When I ask for something, she delivers. Never questioning why I asked for it. We both take turns leading each other to being the best support managers that we can be. She also puts up with my crazy futuristic dance moves and goofy nature within our workspace...lol. Larry. Techmaster. Our program has a couple technically sensitive elements that he has embraced and added value to. He communicates to the vendors that have provided this technology that has allowed key learning opportunities and improvements. [caption id="attachment_1389" align="aligncenter" width="400"] Techmaster[/caption] [caption id="attachment_1390" align="alignleft" width="400"] The Energy[/caption] The Good Guy Robert. Superpower, positive energy management and Mr. fix-it. I have taken the responsibility of making sure that everyone is mentally prepared for the task at hand. The self-proclaimed karma manager, I remind people what a great job we have, what a great life we lead, and that we are the captains of our destiny. I pride myself in keeping the mood light and positive. When other team members or local brand ambassadors are down, I pick them up. By positively reinforcing everyone's value to our goals, I consider my role to be integral and an honor. If stuff is broke, I also have a knack for fixing it. I'm good with my hands. Mirror, headlight or graphic replacement, no problem. I'm your guy. Having a bad day or a slow start, I'm the team's cheerleader.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Lear what super powers each of my team members brings to the table. We're going to need every one of them if this mobile tour has any chance of success.

item.title: The Scorpion & The Frog. Life On The Road. Week 4.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: This week was particularly hard to write about. But I knew this post had to be made. I promised you an insightful and honest account of my 17-week tour. I'm accountable to you, myself and integrity of this blog. I had hoped to report a mostly positive experience. The reality is that life on the road isn't always sunshine and lollipops. Week 4 definitely illustrates this truth. It all starts with me and my roommate, Larry. Larry and I couldn't be more different, a situation I usually celebrate. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy being around people who I have many things in common with. Working and meeting people on the road with the same core values and ideologies as myself is like finding an old friend. Kindred spirits. But what I live for is meeting and getting to know people who are different from myself. It's through these connections that I add more to my life experiences. I have been rewarded immensely by engaging people who are very different from me on the road. [caption id="attachment_1399" align="alignright" width="336"] A Music Loving Extrovert.[/caption] I listen to music that I would've never heard. Gone places that I never would've gone to. Eaten food that I never would've considered eating. I've conquered fears and learned more about myself than one could ever ask for in a lifetime. Shit, after ten years of being on the road, I'm still enjoying new experiences. On this program alone, I've been white water rafting, had my first Cuban sandwich, and had a successful wake boarding adventure. All things I had never done before. And we're only 4 weeks in! And I owe it all to the people who I have been fortunate to have met on the road and in this industry. As I had mentioned earlier, Larry and I couldn't be more different. They say opposites attract. Not so in this situation. Our differences would almost cost us both our jobs. I'm an extrovert. A big reason I love experiential marketing so much is because I get paid to be the person I am when I'm not getting paid. I live big, loud, and with very few regrets. To quote my fellow Good Guy Ryan, "Chuck", as he often refers to me as,".. is very comfortable in his own skin." At 41 years old, I enjoy being a kid at heart. If there's a work day followed by a day off, the last place you'll find me is in my hotel room. I'm living out of a hotel, not a retirement community. Larry is an introvert. From what I've seen, Larry gets satisfaction interacting with the on-line gaming community. I'm also expressive about my passions. Right or wrong, you're guaranteed to hear my honest opinion. And if you ask for my opinion, I won't hesitate to go into great detail about my rationale. Larry's dialog and way of thinking changes based on his environment. Unsure of his surroundings, Larry searches for acceptance by relying on references and accounts of events that are sometimes a challenge to grasp. I used to dismiss his smug heir of superiority as a lack of self-confidence. Someone who needed to be brought along slowly and encouraged. Now, I truly believe he thinks he's better than the rest of the team. Being socially awkward is not a crime. Neither is being an introvert. Larry is OUR guy. We're the only ones allowed to pick on him in the way that we do. If you had a problem with Larry, you had a problem with us. Our team is not shy about teasing each other. Trust me, we all get our fair share of being razzed on in the spirit of fun and levity. Our jobs are serious and sometimes stressful. A laugh is always appreciated and helps keep things in perspective. But the laughing, joking and camaraderie ended when Larry attempted to assassinate my character, call into question my integrity and professionalism to my superiors back the home office. And for a grand finale, he did this all behind the backs of lead tour managers. Breaking the chain of command which didn't put any gleaming smiles on their faces either. Luckily, my consistent performance and positive outlook, made Larry's attempt to get me fired futile. As a matter of fact, it almost backfired and cost him his job. But not without damaging BOTH of our reputations. What is truly sad about the situation is that everyone on the team is paying for it in one way or another. A situation that could've been resolved among two 40-year-old men. What is even sadder is that Larry was starting to grow on me. Now, I have to watch my back and be aware of situations that may even APPEAR inappropriate. The clothes I wear to sleep. The time I come in at. What I do and where I go on my off days. I can't be an adult because Larry chose to be a child. One who finds telling stories easier than telling the truth due to his inability to come to  grips with his own uneventful and uninspired existence. I just struggle to know why all of this had to happen and why he chose this route. And why me? For days and even up until writing this post, I've been puzzled and in a dark place for lack of my understanding. But then I remembered Aesop's Fable of the Scorpion and the Frog. And it was then that my mind was able to find at least some answers. .[su_quote cite="Aesop's Fables"]The Scorpion and the Frog A scorpion and a frog meet on the bank of a stream and the scorpion asks the frog to carry him across on its back. The frog asks, "How do I know you won't sting me?" The scorpion says, "Because if I do, I will die too." The frog is satisfied, and they set out, but in midstream, the scorpion stings the frog. The frog feels the onset of paralysis and starts to sink, knowing they both will drown, but has just enough time to gasp "Why?" Replies the scorpion: "Its my nature..."[/su_quote]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Life on the road isn't always sunshine and lollipops. Week 4 definitely illustrates this truth.It all starts with me and my roommate, Larry.

item.title: Relationships & Mobile Touring. Life On The Road. Week 5.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: So you think dating and being in a committed relationship is a challenge under normal circumstances? Try it while working on the road. It's not impossible, but it requires life skills that Dr. Phil hasn't even thought of yet. Our team covers the gamut of relationship statuses. From single, "it's complicated", to engaged. Matters of the heart and attraction are difficult to understand let alone articulate. I'll do my best to show you what's behind the curtain. The risks and the rewards of  romantic relationships and mobile touring.   Jack & Dianne: Engaged. Jack and Dianne met on the road. As tour-mates. The attraction is easy to assume. As I had mentioned in my previous entry, she is the ying to his yang. They are both uniquely different. What they have in common has proven to provide a solid foundation for their future plans. Everyone would like to think that their relationship is strong and can withstand any adversity. Being on the road provides many opportunities to test those beliefs. Even more so when your co-worker is also your significant other. Just turn on "Amazing Race" and you'll see first hand what I mean. The upside of their relationship on the road is that when they're not working, they're on a potentially romantic and adventurous extended get-away. The downside is that if things aren't going so well or faced with adversity, there's no place to gather thoughts and decompress. No place to just be alone with your thoughts and feelings. You can't just simply ignore calls and texts from your significant other either. Although Jack and Dianne are consummate professionals, one can't help but wonder if there hasn't been a time where personal thoughts and feelings haven't affected them at work in one way or another. I mean after all, we're just human. I've heard horror stories of couples on tours. Break-ups and arguments that eventually spill over into the work environment. Uhhhh. Obviously these situations not only end the relationship but they usually end the couple's employment. But the knife cuts both ways. Couples who can survive a mobile tour grow stronger together and bond tighter than any other environment. Personally and professionally. Jack & Dianne have displayed the ability to balance this difficult dynamic and utilise their relationship as a strength for the program and not a potential weakness. Larry: ? Even before the rift between Larry and I, he didn't share much information in this department. He never talked about past girlfriends, boyfriends, or any other meaningful interactions outside of the virtual world of online gaming. I tried to start some type of dialog to get a better feel of who he was. The guy does sleep in the next bed over from me so I thought some mutual prying would be within my bounds. My earnest attempts to learn about Larry were often met with one-word answers if any at all. Four weeks had gone by and I knew nothing more than what tours he had done in the past, who he knew at what agency, and how many people he blew up the night before. At that point, I was completely puzzled. Little did I know that it might be a warning sign of things to come. Halle: "It's complicated" When it comes to romantic relationships, I'm a bit of a pessimist. Not only because of my pursuit of shared happiness but also because of what I've witnessed people go through in the name of the same pursuit. As pessimistic as I am about my romantic relationships, I hope for the best for the people in my life. That includes Halle.   But enough about me. I'll get to my interesting box of chocolates later. Halle and her boyfriend have been together for two years. Almost as long as she has been touring. Strangely enough, she met her boyfriend touring. On the same team. So naturally the question begs to be asked. "If touring and relationships are so hard, why in the world would you ever date somebody who also tours?" Good question. From the outside, the logic seems twisted and sadistic. But from those of us in the touring industry, the answer is very simple and logical. You see each other every day. Off day. Drive day. Work day. EVERY day. Seeing another person as much as you see your tour-mates provides a plethora of opportunities to get to know someone. We see each other look good. We see each other look bad. And I mean bad folks. Getting up early and working late leaves even the most attractive people look like they just escaped prison on a deserted island. Dirty. Smelly. Tired. Bruised and nicked up. You name it, we've seen it on each other. As disgusting as that might sound, there's an honest nature about it that's surprisingly attractive. We also get to see each other work. Relationships are work and well...... work is work also. Many of the same components that go into executing an event are also found in the dating process. Communication. Teamwork. Problem-solving. Planning. These are just a few. But the biggest reason we date each other is because we understand what we do. Explaining to someone who has never toured is a challenge. Yeah, we can cover the who, what, where, why and when but even in doing so, there's that "it" that one can never convey to another person. The dynamics and experience that is touring. So finding someone who has also been through some of the challenges and crazy situations we've been through is like going to a far distant country and finding someone who speaks the same language. However, Halle's situation is different from Jack and Dianne's. Halle's boyfriend is not on our team, but he's out on the road.  Not a favorable set of circumstances. I wish them both the best. Good Guy Robert: Single Well, I thought I had something when I left for this program. A girl I had sporadically been dating, for almost two years that got more serious in the previous 6 months leading up to the tour. The deal killer. Trust. Even more so than traditional relationships, trust is the number one killer of relationships on the road. I'm confident, outgoing and engaging. I'm surrounded by beautiful people constantly. The latter is the nature of my job. The former is just who I am. These facts are not for the insecure. Especially when it comes to relationships and being on the road. What gets lost on the people who are not on the road is that us road people want something that is real when we reach the end of our work day. Good day or bad day, we put a smile on our faces, roll up our sleeves and leave our thoughts at the hotel door. There's a goal to achieve and team members, clients and supervisors that are counting on us to deliver the goods. We have to set aside our personal problems and our most private thoughts, cares and aspirations to make good on our promise of delivering the best consumer experience possible. Things we hope to find and share with someone who understands who we are, what we do. And how much we appreciate them for doing so.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: So you think dating and being in a committed relationship is a challenge under normal circumstances? Try it while being on a mobile tour. Life on the road.

item.title: We Flex. Life On The Road. Week 6.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: Ahhhhh! A much-needed break. Can you hear me brothers and sisters? Week 6 the team divides and conquers. Jack and Dianne head out west to do what they do best. Execute flawless events at a myriad of predetermined retail  and PR stops. With Larry in tow, it's business as usual but without Halle and I. Halle and I have been given a challenge in another part of the country. To represent our client's brand, at high-profile events, to one of their most important customers. Challenge accepted! Besides, anything to get some space away from Larry and his drama-filled antics is just what the doctor ordered right about now. This is not the first time Halle and I have been trusted with high-profile events. I commonly refer to these type of events as "dragons". Earlier in the tour, we were given a dragon at Twitter's HQ. [caption id="attachment_1434" align="alignleft" width="362"] High-profile events. The dragons of our industry.[/caption] No pressure! Lol. But it was also no problem. Halle and I are dragon killers. I can't help but wonder why we were given another high-profile event. I mean we're supporting members on this program and nobody knows the brand quite like Jack and Dianne. Is it a positioning on diversity? Halle is a young Black female. I look like a Latino. However, there is one thing I'm sure of. We wouldn't be entrusted with these events if Jack and Dianne didn't communicate to the home office that we were more than capable of doing so. It's a great feeling to be given such an awesome responsibility. It's easy to get lost in the fact we are just support managers. The assignment signified that everyone was aware who and what we were before this program. Big dogs. We finally got an opportunity to step out of the shadows and FLEX! Our 3 activation days weren't without their challenges. Many of the big wigs from the brand's corporate team were present. 2 of those days were long and blistering hot. We also had a couple of fires to put out. An event element that didn't want to play nice in the extreme heat and a product ordering oversight. But if anyone was going to pull it off, it was Halle and I. And we did. [caption id="attachment_1436" align="alignright" width="204"] Respect[/caption] There's no secret to our success though. When we work together there are no egos. That allows us to make the most of each other's strengths and cover our weaknesses as a team. If there's something she knows I'm stronger at, she has no problem following my lead or getting out-of-the-way. If there's a skill I know she's better at than me, I do the same. No fuss. No extended deliberations. Just a mutual respect that delivers results. [caption id="attachment_1435" align="alignleft" width="239"] I dance. Like a mad man.[/caption] Oh and how could I forget, she puts up with my goofiness and crazy futuristic dance moves. I just hope that she doesn't steal them and pawn them off as her own...lol.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Life on the road is filled with ups and downs. This week our team separates to cover more ground. Can Halle and I rise up to the challenge of vip events?

item.title: The Golden Oasis. Life On The Road. Week 7.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: Any tour can wear you down. Mentally and physically. Not all at once but gradually. Even the most optimistic and positive personalities start to show signs of wear. By week 7, our tour is starting to show some signs of wear. How we rebound and push forward is what separates those who "would like" to tour from those who "do" tour. [caption id="attachment_1482" align="alignleft" width="362"] Road Wear[/caption] Now don't mistake what I've just said. Yes, our tour has had some challenges and setbacks. Some I've never imagined. Some that are quite common. What adds to an already full plate is what happens outside of our work world. Jack & Dianne are dealing with pulling off a wedding. Halle and her boyfriend recently broke up and I'm trying to fulfill my business vision and mend some family fences. See the picture? Being the self-proclaimed energy manager, I'm sensitive to our team's mood. I also take the responsibility of doing whatever I can to right the ship. Most of the time I hit. Sometimes I miss. But I always try. Our team needed a time out. A time to set aside our work related and non-work related challenges and breathe. No responsibilities. No phone calls. No emails. Just an opportunity to throw all our cares and worries to the curb. Even if only for a moment. This time I would not miss. But I needed some help. And I got it from one of the best. My brother in positive vibes, Brian Goldrich, a.k.a. "Goldy". [caption id="attachment_1487" align="alignright" width="238"] Brian "Goldy" Goldrich & Sam[/caption] Goldy and I met about 6 years ago working on a project. During our training for this project, we instantly clicked. Our personalities and approach to life are very similar, kindred spirits. One of the biggest things we have in common is our reverence for hospitality. You come to our house as a guest, you leave as family. As luck would have it, one of our tour stops was in Goldy's back yard. Fort Collins Colorado. The timing couldn't have been more perfect. We had finally reached our "Golden Oasis". When you're on the road, there's something very soothing about being in a home. Even if it's not your own home. I'm not sure if it's the unique aromas, the decor, or just seeing a real-life framed photo next to the couch. I suppose it's a combination of what a real home IS as much as it is what it's NOT, a cookie cutter hotel room. Walking into Goldy's home and giving my brother the biggest man-hug I could muster instantly lifted my spirits. Although my tourmates were walking into a stranger's home, I knew Goldy's character and personality would make them feel the same. And he did not disappoint. Goldy and his bubbly girlfriend Sam rolled out the red carpet. Treating us to a gourmet home cooked meal and an extensive wine education. Complete with tastings. [caption id="attachment_1484" align="alignleft" width="230"] Feast[/caption] It didn't take long for my co-workers to feel comfortable and begin to enjoy their time at the oasis. Jack, a guy who plays it close to the vest, smiled and laughed more than I had seen the whole entire tour. Halle's eyes started to sparkle again. And well Dianne, she can find a way to have fun at a funeral. The bottom line is that we were starting to return to our pre-tour selves. It was just what the doctor had ordered. [caption id="attachment_1485" align="alignright" width="260"] Fun[/caption] As if the food, libations and conversation weren't enough, the action side of our team's character was also satisfied. The team got a chance to burn off our meal and some steam with a skateboarding adventure to a nearby lake complete with a paddle boat story that I still can't stop chuckling about. [caption id="attachment_1486" align="alignleft" width="262"] Lake Adventure[/caption] Time flies when you're having fun. We were having a blast. Unfortunately, our night would eventually come to an end. Time to call the cab. I'd have to say goodbye to my brother and his awesome girlfriend, not sure when I'd see them again. That's how it is on the road. But I was grateful for the time we did get to hang out and for opening his home to complete strangers. I also tip my hat to my co-workers. For accepting my invitation to the unknown. Keeping an open mind. And for leaving our roles, responsibilities, and woes at the door. For one night, we were together. Like friends.

item.title: Stop Breaking Stuff! Life On The Road. Week 8.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: Breaking stuff can be frustrating. It's one thing when unforeseen design flaws or eventual wear and tear causes things to break. It's another thing when you've had a personal hand in causing something to break. By week 8, we've all had some event element or vital tool break on our watch. When you look back at it, it's funny and provides lessons in human error. In the moment, it's no laughing matter. What's not so funny about it is that these events never happen at a convenient moment. Shops and repair facilities are usually closed. If they are open, you're usually days if not weeks from a viable and durable solution. And we're talking about the event elements and tools that aren't customized. And it undoubtedly comes at the expense of any free time in our schedule. You're resourcefulness, creativity, and inner mechanical engineer are truly tested. When I tell my non-industry friends some of the challenges we've faced as road warriors, the next question is always...."Well, what did you do?" The answers always leave them in complete amazement. With an emphatic yes, we make McGyver look like a windshield wiper replacement tech at your local quick lube. [caption id="attachment_1515" align="alignleft" width="114"] McGyver[/caption] But these moments provide an invaluable index of how-to's that can't be taught in any classroom or YouTube video. This is how we earn our pay. By this time of the tour, I've broken a side mirror. Another large vehicle decided to trade paint during my drive through Atlanta. Fortunately, my mirror was the only casualty. A repair easily handled by my past experience and a trip to the local auto parts store. [caption id="attachment_1512" align="alignleft" width="319"] Broken Mirror[/caption] My generator's fuel tank also suffered from being pierced by a combination of corrosion and construction debris. A temporary patch and some luck would still keep my vehicle functional until a permanent solution could be scheduled. Our main event element's trailer window would shatter shortly after a hail storm during Halle's watch. Our best friend, Google search and mass next day dialing to nearby service options. And when I say dialing, I mean dialing like we're calling a Christian radio station for live Jesus concert tickets. Larry would improperly hitch this same event element to our chase vehicle. An inevitable bump in the road would cause this event element to come unhitched and crash into the towing vehicle. A sigh of relief. [caption id="attachment_1513" align="alignleft" width="270"] Larry's Mis-Hitch[/caption] This could have been so much worse considering the circumstances surrounding this mishap. The trailer or the towing vehicle could've been damaged to the point of no repair. Or the worse case, Larry could've been hurt. Yes, as I stated earlier, we are good at what we do. We can come up with solutions and solve problems that leave non-industry people in amazement. But I'd rather be lucky than good any day of the week. The tour Gods would see that we got that luck. And when we needed it most. Although we may never be featured on "World's Most Dangerous Jobs", this profession can be dangerous. Either by our own hand, wear and tear or by unforeseen design flaws, things will break. [caption id="attachment_1514" align="alignleft" width="252"] We Don't Break[/caption] What makes me most proud about being a professional in this industry is that although things may break, our ability to come up with solutions, our commitment to each other and our spirits don't break.

item.title: Larry Quits. My Parting Words To Him. Life On The Road. Week 9.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Ahhhhhh Larry. If you could see the smile on my face right now, you'd be vomiting Tilapia all over yourself. Ya know my brother, it'd be so easy to stoop to your level. Call you out for who you really are at this point in your life. Bash your character, the whole nine yards. And if the social media world knew the whole truth regarding your actions and the circumstances, I'd be well within my right to do so.

But this is just me and you.

And I know you're listening.

You quit because you were in an environment that you could no longer endure.

An environment that YOU created.

For reasons, I may never understand.

[caption id="attachment_1568" align="alignleft" width="321"] Difficult Environment[/caption] Why you did it? I have no idea. Maybe one day, when you've resolved your own internal battles, we can share our thoughts over a nice cold one. As strange as that thought may sound to you, I welcome the opportunity. Why not? It's a small world after all. Right? It's no secret that I'm striving to be the best person I can possibly be. Both personally and professionally. Although I'm not perfect, it doesn't stop me from trying. So what I'm about to say may catch you off guard but it's the truth. I am truly grateful to the powers that "be" that they brought you into my life. Ya see Larry, one thing that I truly cling to at this point in my journey is that the only bad experience is the experience that one doesn't learn from. Our time together has taught me so much. Some new things and some things that I already knew but just needed a reminder of. And that's where I draw my gratitude from. As appreciative as I am for the experience and the lessons I've learned, I'd also like to share how great things are now that you're gone. I love our team. [caption id="attachment_1565" align="alignleft" width="362"] Fun Times[/caption] As individuals and as a whole. We smile more. Laugh more. And we have more fun times. But most importantly we have a  renewed sense of commitment to each other and our work. And the guy that replaced you...well, he might not be able to teach me some of the valuable things you taught me. I'll just have to deal with his outgoing personality and easy going nature. We'll probably have to pass the remaining time on this tour talking about the many things we've already found in common with each other. But I digress. As I said earlier, I'm still a work in progress. However, as grateful as I am for our time together as team members and as roomies, I feel obligated to offer some advice in return. Thoughts and words that have served me well.
  • Listen more than you speak.
  • Allow someone else to shine. By lifting others up you'll find that they will return the favor when the opportunity presents itself.
  • Be yourself. Not everyone will like you, but at least they'll respect you for taking the courage to be who you are and not for who you think they want you to be.
  • Be consistent.
  • Learn to laugh. Especially at yourself. People say they like perfection but what they truly admire is humanity. Laughing at yourself shows others that you are just like them. Human.
  • If you make a mistake. Own up to it. We've all made mistakes.
  • Consider yourself a problem-solver. Not one who points them out. Always go to the source first.
  • Treat others as you'd like to be treated.
  • Even though your actions may fail, this does not condemn your life to failure. Failure is an event not a person.

I know you like fantasy and science-fiction, but try watching a classic western every once in a while.

They're my favorite genre of movie and provide so much inspiration.

You know why?

Because in the end.

The "Good Guy" always wins.

item.title: Visiting My Roots. Life On The Road. Week 10.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: I often feel like an astronaut being on the road. I pack. Say goodbye to most of my friends and family. Get into a vehicle. Not to be seen again for months at a time. [caption id="attachment_1574" align="alignleft" width="362"] Being An Astronaut.[/caption] My vehicle takes me to places most will never see in their lifetime. As glamorous as it sounds, these amazing travels come at a price. When I return, I'm surrounded by change. Whether it's a new building in my city's landscape, a road that once was now no longer, a growth spurt of a child, or the engagement of a friend, life moves on in your absence.   Living in Las Vegas for the past 8 years, these changes are more dramatic when I visit Cleveland. Sometimes the "tour gods" are cruel. The travel schedule puts you nowhere near your home. Sometimes they smile upon you, putting your travels right on your doorstep. In my case, they'd be like a bag of my favorite candy. Sour Patch Kids. Sour at first. Sweet in the end. Nowhere near my home but right on the doorsteps of my roots, Cleveland Ohio. [caption id="attachment_1579" align="alignright" width="400"] My Hometown. Cleveland, Ohio.[/caption] Although I've been back to Cleveland many times during my travels on the road, it had been almost 2 years since my last visit. Talk about overdue. Nothing, and I mean nothing is more heartbreaking than telling your friends and loved ones that you're close-by, but you might not have an opportunity to see them. Either because your days are jam-packed or because you're there for only one day, it's always news that's hard to break. When I first got into mobile touring, these conversations were not well-received. Feeling like I had snubbed them, sometimes I'd often wonder if I was better off not telling them at all. It was just so hard for them to understand. Now that I've been doing this for a while, my friends and family are much better about it. But this time would be different than my last visits. Not only would I be back in my hometown, I'd also be given the rare luxury of downtime. [caption id="attachment_1576" align="alignleft" width="400"] Me & My Cuz Jen[/caption] They wouldn't have to take any days off just for the opportunity to see my face and I wouldn't have to get creative or go without sleep for a chance to see theirs. Going home under these circumstances was liberating and rejuvenating. I'd make the most of it. Not only would I get to see most of my family and inner circle of friends, I'd also get to be amongst my people, Clevelanders. I'd walk down my favorite city streets. As I walked, people would say hello. Not because they knew me, it's just what we as Clevelanders do. Open doors for each other. Let other drivers out into traffic. Say thank you. Other stuff that we as Clevelanders do. Eat my favorite Cleveland foods and hang out at my favorite haunts. It was great to see how my hometown had changed for the better. It also revealed how much I had changed. The last time I had been back, my city was still suffering from the departure of a certain homegrown NBA player. [caption id="attachment_1577" align="alignright" width="320"] Looks Better In A Cavs Uniform.[/caption] Even though people from other cities make fun and poke jokes about the city where I'm from, there's no place on Earth that I'd rather be from. Yeah, I got a little pride about where I was raised. More so than any other of my friends or colleagues....lol. I'm grateful that I got an opportunity to spend time with family and old friends. I got to reminisce. Laugh. And be reminded how important it is to never forget where I'm from. No matter where the road or this life takes me, I'll always be a Clevelander.

item.title: The FNG. Life On The Road. Week 11.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
With Larry gone, a break in our schedule and being in my home state of Ohio, things were quickly becoming "sunshine & lollipops" for the whole team. Obviously, I'd benefit the most from these set of circumstances but there was a general sense of relief and optimism throughout. [caption id="attachment_1586" align="alignleft" width="201"] Us Four. A Team.[/caption] Finally! Just the four of us. Adults and professionals who had already been through some thick and thin times together since day one. With a tour this short and not too many weeks until the end, it's hard to tell how close our time together will bond us. Or how long that bond will last. But one thing is for sure, at this point of the tour we have more than a basic understanding of who we are as individuals. We also have an elevated level of mutual respect for each other since being brought together. From an agency point of view, there was only one problem. The client signed up for six road managers. We were down to four. Like a kid who had snuck an extra cookie from the jar, I held my breath. Waiting to see if anyone had noticed. Or if anything would be done about it. [caption id="attachment_1588" align="aligncenter" width="362"] Did Anyone Notice?[/caption] To my chagrin. Somebody noticed. And yes, something would be done about it. I had caught a temporary case of "stinkin' thinkin'.' Great. Here we go again. We were getting another team member. A guy. I was getting another roommate. As I had mentioned earlier, I wasn't overly thrilled when I got the news. At first my thoughts were.... [caption id="attachment_1585" align="alignright" width="312"] Stinkin' Thinkin'[/caption]
  • Shit. Can I get a break?
  • Why does it have to be a guy?
  • There weren't any qualified female candidates available?
  • Halle has had 9 weeks without a roomie. Can we spread this situation around somewhat evenly?
  • Do we really want to risk the chance of getting another Larry?
  • I have to go through the entire process of getting to know another stranger who I'll have to share living quarters with. AGAIN.
I had also felt slightly snubbed because the agency hadn't reached out to me regarding Larry's replacement or asked for any suggestions. I thought that I had earned some currency with the home office with my work performance or at the very least for enduring my previous situation. In doing so, I felt that my character and credibility had been unquestionably validated to everyone. These thoughts were unlike me and not who I aspire to be. Stinking thinking at its worst. Fortunately, I'd have a few days to myself, in my own space, to meditate and rid myself of these negative thoughts before our new guy would arrive. [caption id="attachment_1589" align="aligncenter" width="362"] I had to refocus on the positives.[/caption] When I emerged, I had a new and much more positive perspective on our new guys impending arrival.
  • Jack & Dianne found our new guy. They know me and my personality. I trust them. Jack & Dianne wouldn't offer anyone up to the agency that wouldn't be a good fit for my extroverted persona and lifestyle.
  • The agency has confidence in my ability to bounce back from the challenges of my previous environment.
  • I get an opportunity to meet a person that could potentially add value to my life and my experiences.
  • I get an opportunity to positively affect someone else's.
  • The exception and not the rule, not everyone is a Larry.
With my mental compass adjusted, I was ready to meet the new guy. Going about my business in my hotel sanctuary, I got a call from Jack. Jack: "Hey, we're grabbing lunch. Want to come with us?" Me: "Sure." Jack: "Cool. We'll be by to pick you up in 10." I knew the new guy would be with them. Time to practice what I preach. As I opened the car door, there was my new teammate and roomie. It was mildly nervous. Kind of like first date nervous. And I think the rest of the team felt this same wait and see anticipation. Our first interaction would go something like this.... FNG: "Hey, my name is Doc." Not quite ready to call him brother. This term would have to be earned. Me: "Hey, my name is Robert. Or you can call me Rob. Just don't call me Bob or Bobby and we'll be good." Doc: " That's cool man. Nice to meet you." [caption id="attachment_1587" align="alignleft" width="270"] Common Intrests[/caption] Me: "Same.....I love motorcycles and I'm learning about photography and videography for a project I'm working on." Doc: "I own a motorcycle, snowboard and I'm pretty good with a camera." I confidently declare to the rest of the team....."He's ok with me." You could almost feel the tension disappear from the air. Me and the team were going to be just fine.

item.title: The Missing Link. Life On The Road. Week 12.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: With the arrival of Doc, our first priority was to get him settled in and up to speed. Not an easy task. On both ends. Doc was joining a team that was already in full stride in our roles, responsibilities and workflow. Watching a cohesive team operate, like ours, is poetry in motion. Once Jack & Dianne have laid down the framework of our activation, every part knows exactly what needs to be done and when it needs to be done. Because every activation is uniquely different, things aren't always done in the same order. Nor is it necessarily done by the same person. What's so amazing is that it always gets done. With very minimal verbal communication. And that's the beauty of it. The challenge in getting a new team member up to speed is to figure out what their strengths and weaknesses are. And how to incorporate those strengths and minimize any weaknesses within the machine. Joining a team at this juncture can frustrate most people. Watching us as we perform in the way that we do, the new person often gets caught in slow motion. Often feeling useless or invaluable. This where we'd find out what Doc was made of. I'd hope for the best but sometimes you never know. I reminded myself that Jack and Dianne chose Doc for a reason. We also have a very unselfish and supportive team. Jack gives great direction. Dianne has unlimited patience and Halle knows every small detail. As Doc's roommate, I'd also be available to answer questions or bring clarity after hours. In addition to our support, there were two things about Doc that assured me that he wouldn't frustrate so easily. Being from the mid-west, he knows hard work. Or at the very least knows what it looks like. [caption id="attachment_1596" align="aligncenter" width="362"] Steel Mills of the Mid-West.[/caption] And a snowboarder. Who has ever met an uptight skateboarder, surfer or snowboarder? They also don't get frustrated easily. Having a few friends, who also have a passion for action sports, I've witnessed them attempt tricks countless times. To the point that I start to feel frustrated for them. [caption id="attachment_1597" align="alignleft" width="287"] Doc. The Snowboarder.[/caption] Coming so close to nailing that trick but falling short. But time and time again, they get back on that board or make that climb back up the mountain with the same enthusiasm and optimism as the first time they attempted it. What I didn't know was that Doc had a few tricks up his sleeve. For one, you only have to show the guy something once and he gets it. Since I require repetition, this is an ability that I've always admired in others who possess this skill. And two, he's already worked for the brand before. Although it wasn't a mobile tour, he had already been immersed in the brand's culture and key talking points at a multi-day activation. Sneaky bastard. Well played. Incorporating Doc's skill and knowledge into our running team would happen almost seamlessly. Along with his laid back approach and willingness to work hard, we had found our missing link.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The missing link.Life on the road. Week 12. Follow me as I give you an inside look at my 17-week mobile marketing tour. This week, getting Doc settled in.

item.title: Team Building. Life On The Road. Week 13.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: With some solid training, his past experience, and a few events under his belt, Doc was now up to speed. Just in time for a few days off. Talk about luck. If there was ever a good time to break into a running tour, this was it. It's one thing when you have a week, or two if you're lucky, to get ready for the road. It's completely another when you get plucked from your everyday life. To those who have never toured before, imagine wrapping up all your affairs and saying your goodbyes in an 18-hour window. Oh, but wait! Did you pack everything you think you might need for the next month? [caption id="attachment_1616" align="alignleft" width="207"] Everything Must Go! Including You![/caption] By the way, besides your carry-on, you only get one bag. And that bag better be under 50 lbs or the extra charges come out of your pocket. Ok, now off to another city that most likely isn't in your time zone. No big deal right? Wrong. Odds are, in order to stay in budget, you've been booked on an economy itinerary. Probably not a direct flight. Welcome to the program...now read this. Know this. Meet them and review this. Sign this, this, and this. Now here's the keys to the vehicle you'll be responsible for the rest of the tour. And lastly, lobby call tomorrow is at  6 am. 4 hours of rest should be enough for you, right? We know you'll do a great job and good luck! It can be a little nerve-racking. When I think back to the first time I was 'plucked', I was grateful for my military experience. Without it, I think my head would have pinwheeled. [caption id="attachment_1622" align="alignright" width="362"] Off & Running[/caption] A few days off, after starts like these, makes a world of difference. Watching him selflessly contribute, at our next large-scale event, it was obvious that we had been upgraded. "Let me pay my dues" was a phrase I'd hear him reverberate throughout his first few days. Kinda refreshing to hear. Being 14 years his senior, I didn't think his generation knew what "dues" were. I'd stand corrected. Although I've found him to be a quick study, he didn't let the rough spots discourage his efforts. Besides, he'd have plenty of opportunities to work out any kinks over the next couple of days. But before discovering how well we'd all work with Doc, we got an opportunity to see how the entire team would vibe without the confines of roles and responsibilities. It was team building time! Cedar Point!!!! Yes! Right in my wheelhouse. What's great about these types of activities is that we get to shed our version of the corporate world. Just be ourselves. Yeah, we talk shop here and there but it's in a much different context. In our team's case, we usually roast each other for doing something stupid. Or we reflect on how funny a certain aspect of a past event was. Nothing is off-limits. At any rate, it's money well spent by the agency and brings a little levity to our life that is greatly appreciated. Strangely enough it actually helps build the team. Funny how that works. Jack & Dianne have had an uncanny ability to get our bosses to pay for many of our adventures. Dinners. Gift cards to Starbucks. Wake boarding trips. The works. I've been to more of these agency-sponsored events than on any other program. I would have been on more adventures with our team if I wasn't so fearful of getting injured on one of these exploits. With no real health insurance, business aspirations in my sights, responsibilities to take care of and nobody to rely on other than myself, I carefully evaluate the risks of getting sidelined. [caption id="attachment_1614" align="aligncenter" width="341"] Adrenaline Junkies[/caption] Whether they like to admit it or not, my team is composed of  adrenaline junkies. And now we've added a 27-year-old former professional snowboarder. Awesome! I'm now not only the undisputed "old man" of the team, I've also become the most boring. Somebody tell Larry to get back here...lol.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: With some solid training, his past experience, and a few events under his belt, Doc was now up to speed.Just in time for a few days off. Life on the road.
Life On The Road. Team Building. Week 13

item.title: Our Biggest Mountain. Life On The Road. Week 14.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
By week 14 we had climbed just about every mountain, as far as events go.

As a team, we had flawlessly executed VIP events, corporate events, guerilla events, sponsorship events, sporting events and everything else in between. But there was one event that Jack, Dianne, and the home office had circled on their calendar.

Revere Beach.

Our biggest mountain.

In my management support role, I learned a new skill early on in this program. How to sit back and trust other, more than capable, parts of the team to do what they do best.

Lead.

The team never lacks the desire to assist Jack & Dianne when it comes to executing a task or errand.

The art we've learned is when to offer ideas.

When Jack & Dianne get deadlocked, they can trust us to offer a different solution to a challenge.

And they have no problem running with that solution.

This particular event would provide a number of obstacles.

[caption id="attachment_1633" align="aligncenter" width="362"] Overcoming Obstacles[/caption]
  1. Our footprint: The venue didn't correctly account for our space needs.[su_spacer size="30"]
  2. Quality of local support staff: Overall, we had good staff but it only takes a couple weak links to make an event of this size more challenging. We had one or two that just didn't quite "get it".[su_spacer size="30"]
  3. Volume: This would be our most highly attended event. Flow strategy would be essential to ensuring that every attendee left with a positive experience with the brand.[su_spacer size="30"]
  4. Maintaining the quality of the product we were demonstrating / sampling: Because of the sheer numbers, we'd have to make additional preparations to deliver consistency.[su_spacer size="30"]
  5. Resource management: This was a 3-day event. We had to be mindful of our resources. Inventory, fuel, water and most importantly ourselves. This was a marathon, not a race. Improper management of these resources could potentially make this event a disaster.
But this is what we live for and how we earn our pay. If we didn't have the skills or experience to handle seemingly difficult circumstances, we might as well hang up our keys and grab a desk. Nah! Did the desk thing for 8 years. To borrow a fisherman's adage, my worst day in the field is better than any day behind a desk. Well, for the most part...lol. Revere Beach would indeed live up to the billing as being our highest volume event. Head and shoulders above any of our previous events. You can usually find me dancing about in my event area as if it were my last day on Earth. When I was made aware of the numbers we'd be doing, I made a conscious effort to pace myself.

But just like Big Pun said... "It's so hard".

[caption id="attachment_1631" align="alignright" width="338"] My Super Bowl[/caption]

I feed off the energy of big events.

It's my Super Bowl Sunday.

Meeting tons of new people.

Introducing something that is new to them.

The conversations.

  Accepting the challenge and delivering the experience is my Lombardi trophy. Something that my previous career just couldn't quite provide. However, performing at a high level also has its cost. By day 3 of our 12 hour days, I'd start to feel it. Even more so than my other teammates, Dianne and I have a very familiar understanding of each other. I suppose it's mainly because of our only child upbringing and experiences. [caption id="attachment_1627" align="aligncenter" width="238"] Only Child Syndrome[/caption] In charge of entertaining ourselves, creating our own brand of humor and thinking, we have a mutual appreciation for our approach to life and how we interact with others. When I make one of my many contorted facial movements or body gestures, most folks can see the wheels turning. What's both funny and spooky is that she's able to verbally translate what those ticks mean. [caption id="attachment_1629" align="alignleft" width="199"] Past Emcee[/caption]

I consider it a gift.

A gift I'd appreciate halfway through day 3.

Sensing that I had needed a change, I got to polish off my emcee skills and was handed the mic.

Just the recharge I needed to get me to the finish line.

I take pride in maintaining a level of energy that rivals many of my younger colleagues. By the end of the day, I admittedly felt my age.

My trusted sidekick, Red Bull, would be of no help today.

What was somewhat comforting to know was that Doc and Halle felt my age too.

[caption id="attachment_1630" align="aligncenter" width="293"] Victory[/caption]

We all had worked harder and pushed further than we had at any other activation  for this program.

It paid off.

We were victorious.

As a team.

  Climbing our biggest mountain would have to be celebrated in the comfort of a healing hot bath at the hotel.

The stories of our day's experiences would have to wait until the next day.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I never realized just how demanding your career is. I have a much higher respect for what you do. Hope that life continues to be all that it can be for you.
Thank you for those kind words.Do you have a favorite week in the blog series?

item.title: The End Is Near. Life On The Road. Week 15
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: With only two weeks left in the program, there was a reality just right around the corner. The reality that the end is near. When I tell my non-industry friends that I'm leaving for 5 months, 8 months or a year for work, it's always met with a blank look of amazement. I guess they can't wrap their heads around not being home for so long. What's funny is that we, as professional tour staff, can't imagine being in one place for too long. Winding down a tour is very different to me than getting one on the road. When you start a program, it's all about the team and its ability to function as one cohesive unit.Towards the end , you start to focus on what you need to do and how life is going to be after your last day. Sounds selfish doesn't it? But our team of seasoned veterans know the drill and take no exception with each other for our change of focus. I mean who wants to arrive at their final destination with no job and no place to live? As crazy as that may sound, that was indeed my reality. Just before leaving, I moved all my stuff into a storage unit. Yay! I wouldn't have to pay rent or a mortgage for 5 months. The flip side is that when I arrive back home to Vegas, I'd be jobless and homeless. As dire as that might sound, we still have resources. Hotel points from our travels that can be redeemed for free stays and a  stash of funds from our hard work. Far from being destitute, the art of planning ahead, spending conservatively, lessens the anxiety that comes with the transition. When the tour ends, we are all going our separate ways. But before doing so we all ask the same question. What's next? I have a tendency to quietly freak out, at about this time, for every tour. Coming from a regular 9 to 5 with a guaranteed check for many years, I can't help but feel somewhat anxious. Uncertainty will do that to you I guess. What was different about this program, from the other programs I've been a part of, was a slight sense of sadness. We had come to the point of the tour where most of us could order food for each other. Put another's belongings in a place that made sense to their owners. Finish each other's jokes. But what ultimately proved to be a symbol of our bond was the ability to imitate each other. Voices. Mannerisms. The whole nine yards. It's possible, but not likely, that the five of us would ever work with each other again. When that truth hit me, the thought of "what's next" became somewhat secondary. Through 15-weeks, we had been through some stuff. Not to say that we didn't have our fare share of fun times and adventures. But when you go through some adversity, as we did, and your teammate is still there with you..... Well, those are the moments that characters are defined and friendships are measured. Knowing that we had only two more weeks left, I'd do my best to slow down time. Finding people in life who can endure the ups and downs are hard to come by. What can be even harder is letting them go.

item.title: What's Next? Life On The Road. Week 16
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
There are principles about time that we sometimes forget. But when we remember them they ring loud and true. Time flies when you're having fun. Time also drags on forever when you're not. I'd have my share of them both. As I reflected on the past 15 weeks, it be became even more clear. I wasn't ready to go home. The industry and the lifestyle that I had been accustomed to for so long, before taking a year-long hiatus, had hooked me again. Was I surprised? Yes, I was.

I thought that getting a taste of the things that had jaded me into retirement would remind me why I had made that decision.

[caption id="attachment_1691" align="alignleft" width="175"] Putting Out Fires[/caption] The long hours. The countless miles. Switching from hotel to hotel. Stuff breaking. Spending my off days fixing them. Dealing with staff that just didn't quite "get it". And most importantly, being a spectator in the movie theatre of life. Watching the lives of my friends and family go by across the screen. However, I came to a realization. For all that life on the road is NOT, there's so much more that it IS. Of course there's the obvious perks. Meeting new people. Exploring and appreciating the constantly changing office view. The satisfaction of facing adversity and overcoming it. Accumulating ridiculous amounts of hotel points and eating on somebody else's dime. The camaraderie. But only through my 4 other teammate's eyes, would I find what was not so obvious. I had new experiences. New adventures. New skills and life lessons. I also gained a new appreciation for my past experiences. At 41 years-old, I know I can't tour forever. [caption id="attachment_1683" align="alignright" width="383"] Classic Reborn[/caption] But somehow, unbeknownst to them, my colleagues had turned back the miles on this classic's odometer. Now only two questions remained. What would my next tour opportunity be? And who did I want to work with if anyone at all? Ok, well technically 3. Jack and Dianne were out. With their upcoming nuptials, touring would have to be placed on the back burner. At least for the immediate future. Halle was out. As the countdown to the tour's end drew nearer, Halle's excitement of going home grew larger. It was clear that she was ready to go home. With a sister waiting for her in an apartment she had barely lived in, who could blame her? And then there was Doc. It was no secret that Doc and I had hit it off practically from day one. [caption id="attachment_1687" align="alignright" width="306"] "Laverne and shirley 1976" by American Broadcasting Company (ABC)[/caption] Jack had cleverly dubbed us Laverne & Shirley. How he came up with that gem I have no clue. The spontaneity of it still makes me chuckle. If it wasn't for my "wait and see" approach, it probably would've been day one. What can I say? A Larry episode can do that to you. Even as well as we connected, it would've have been presumptuous to assume that he'd want to roll with me. So I asked. It kinda went like this... Good Guy Robert: "Hey Doc." Doc: "What's up?" Good Guy Robert: "Would you be down to roll with me on another tour?" Doc: "Hell yeah! When do we start?" The confidence in his voice reassured me what I already knew. That he'd be just as dedicated and easy to work with as he was on our current tour. The hint of sarcasm also reminded me of another fact. Getting another tour, this late in the season, wouldn't be easy. There's a lot of dogs fighting for even fewer bones. Although other successful tour managers dismiss their steady work-load as pure luck, at some point there was work involved in getting it. In addition to relentlessly pursuing every lead, we'd need to utilize our resources and maintain our confidence. To have faith that our persistence, complimentary skill sets and effort would eventually pay off. Preferably sooner than later.   If we've got any chance of getting another tour this year, Doc and I would have to pull our resources together. And quickly.

item.title: It's A Wrap! Life On the Road. Week 17
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
The last week on the road was ceremonious in so many ways. Our last event seemed like a gala affair. Our evening, filled with fireworks. Our departure, a mixture of somber moments traced with laughter and inside jokes. All the time I kept thinking to myself, would I ever see these uniquely awesome individuals again? I had grown attached to each one of my tour-mates in one way or another. [caption id="attachment_1747" align="aligncenter" width="400"] Good Times[/caption] We had been through some tough situations together.
