What had set this group apart, from other teams I have toured with, was that no matter how difficult times were, we still managed to find a way to laugh and have fun. For our diligence and ability to rise above adversity, karma would reward us with a peaceful and happy ending. As we prepared for our last event, each of us processed the end of the tour in our own way. I usually don't wind down tours with the emotional value as I did this one. But like I said, this group was special to me. Fortunately, our last event was like Christmas. [caption id="attachment_1746" align="alignright" width="256"] Like Christmas[/caption] A supplier event for a large retail chain outlet. Can you say freebies out the ying yang? Similar to NACS, held in Las Vegas, suppliers were wall to wall in the St. Paul Convention Center. Hoping to get more shelving space at retail locations, suppliers were eager to get their products into attendees hands. Or into anybody's hands for that matter. This event was a smorgasbord of freebies and samples that catered to each one of our carnal needs. We'd each take turns, covering our areas of responsibility, to gather freebee intel. Who had what. And were was it. Because we had come to know each other's likes and dislikes, the scouting reports would've made the greatest military minds proud. Doc and I would be handed the "sugar" report. Jack & Dianne would be handed the "healthy and natural" report. And Halle would be handed the "practical" report. After we gathered all that we could reasonably ship or fly home with, it was clear who the day's winners were. Me and Doc.

We had scored FREE FIREWORKS!

[caption id="attachment_1741" align="aligncenter" width="298"] Free Fireworks![/caption]

Are you effin' kidding me?! Are you serious?!

No, I'm not and yes I am.

The sheer school-girl giddiness of getting a shit ton of free firework occupied the turning gears of my mind and our inevitable separation. Later that night we'd meet in the hotel parking lot to share the grand prize of all the spoils. The ladies, resting on the hood of our tour tanks, would enjoy the show. The fellas would compete for the oohs and ahhhhs by progressively adding more fireworks to each launching. Not quite professional, 100 feet in the air, grade fireworks, I was able to catch their smiles one more time from the light and sparks. [caption id="attachment_1740" align="aligncenter" width="362"] Sharing Our Spoils[/caption] This was my crew. And this was our last night together. Dianne and I operate mentally at the same frequency. So when she drew us together for the evenings final remarks I wasn't surprised. It's what I would've done had I found the words. Her comments reassured me that I wasn't being an old over-analytical sap. That this tour tested her strength, validated her abilities, and provided personal growth. What we all had felt, Dianne put into words. Our head nods and glares at the ground confirmed that we were also grateful for her doing so. The next day I made it a point to finish like I had started. Strong. [caption id="attachment_1743" align="aligncenter" width="453"] The Sultan of Sugar[/caption] Duke, the Bush's Baked Beans mascot, and costume characters from my favorite sugar-filled brands, would make my day less cerebral. When our day had concluded, there was no more product to prepare. And no more brand messages to convey. With the trucks all packed and ready to go, this in fact was the end. It goes so fast. One thing that always amazes me about life on the road. 5 months just flies like a week. [caption id="attachment_1749" align="alignleft" width="400"] Our Last Pose[/caption] After giving each other our farewell hugs there was one last picture to snap. We'd all pile on to the end of our tour vehicles. Grabbing poles, rails, or anything we could use to capture that last memorable picture. Striking our last pose, quite possibly forever as a group. One. Two. Three. Cheese! Snap. That's a wrap.

item.title: The Ultimate Thank You Card
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
[su_quote cite="Julie Plake of Marc USA"]Robert, What a journey this has been! You asked me the moment I "trusted" you guys and I finally figured it out. When I got a call after the field invasion in Philly from the RA people and they said how smooth it went & how awesome you guys were! I knew I could let go of "a little" control. Thanks most of all for being so accommodating to whatever "crazy needs" and last minute changes! Thanks for all the pizza & all the fun! xo. "the boss"    [/su_quote] [su_quote cite="Bethany Tillis of Marc USA"]Robert, To the guy who always knows how to keep calm - if I ever get stuck on a broken down bus with 30 8-year olds agin, I'll know who to call for backup! Had a great time working with you guys...we'll miss you! Keep in touch![/su_quote] [su_quote cite="Cheryly Sills of Marc USA"]Robert, You are truly amazing. Everything you do is classy, cool and so smooth. You care so much about people and it shows in all you do. You made RA 50 work!! I wish you safe journeys![/su_quote]

[su_quote cite="Heather Kratsas of Marc USA"]Robert, How is even possible to put into words how grateful I am that we snagged you for this tour? You were a huge part of why this program has been so successful and not fell apart so many times. I appreciate all of your hard work, smart thinking on your feet, dedication to our mission, and constant friendly smile & hug. I know you went above & beyond for us and it meant a ton to me. You're a pro & I wish you the best wherever your journeys take you. Let us know when you're around Pittsburgh next!![/su_quote]

item.title: Giving Thanks. Life On The Road.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Thank You

The "Life On The Road" series was a risky yet passionate project, in my eyes. Who could be reading? What would they think? If only one person gained value or insight, I knew that documenting this tour was well worth it. It is because of the individual, reading this right now, that pushed me forward. Thank You.

Doc

Some may draw a conclusion about this story. That my survival of this tour was due to the departure, of a then, negative energy. Looking back, I would say that your arrival was just as important. You restored my faith and provided a level of energy that I was in need of. They say everything happens for a reason. By bringing your "what the hell, why not?" attitude to the program gave credence to that adage.

Halle

The only thing predictable about touring is that eventually something  unpredictable is going to happen. I watched you navigate through a wide range of life's unpredictability. You were my favorite "live" newsfeed on the road. How you assess situations and work through challenges, is a skill I've witnessed you grow unbelievably strong and confident in. But even in your moments of weakness and vulnerability, you reminded me of a valuable lesson. That it's ok to admit how something affects you mentally or emotionally. It isn't about articulation but conviction. It's one thing to articulate yourself, under certain circumstances, with words that are measured and effective. Letting your world know the emotions you are feeling, without calculating each word is brave. You are a brave woman Halle. I look forward to reading your story and its countless rises over challenging goals.

Dianne

When I look back, at our time spent together on the road, two undeniable words come to mind. Faith & Trust. There was plenty of wait and see from both of us. One thing we learned about each other quickly, we both appreciate and practice intelligent diplomacy. The process of developing trust and faith in each other, and realizing how much we have in common as a result is an experience I will never forget. By keeping faith in the process that brought us together, trusting each other became much easier. It didn't hurt that we were actually qualified for our positions....lol. However, it was your humble nature and willingness to admit a mistake that won me over. Both, rare qualities in our line of work. Yet these two unapologetic extroverts, realized that we both believe in similar core values. The human race is generally good. We should do our part to help each other be a part of that positive change. But never take our kindness as a form of weakness. And your level of patience is an example that I will continue to strive for.

Jack

I voiced my passion for the event-marketing. How I wanted to help bring much needed change to the industry. And how The Good Guys forum has been an active participant in opening and contributing dialog for that change. Without your encouragement and guidance, The Life On The Road series literally wouldn't exist. I know you were probably saying to yourself,"What in the hell did I just start?" And, "Is the conversation we shared going to come back to bite me, Dianne, or this tour in the ass?" It was your words, that inspired 17-weeks of evaluation and honest reflection. Some weeks were hard to write about. Then there were the weeks I couldn't wait to write about. Your gift to me has turned into a gift to all. To those who have no concept of what we do to top-notched professionals in our field. Your support and genuine investment in my success has given our family and friends a better understanding. Not just about our work but also about what life on the road is really like. That although our lives might seem glamorous and filled with adventure, that we share the same dreams and challenges as our 9 - 5 family and friends in the pursuit of success and happiness. At the time, you took a big risk. We barely knew each other nor my intentions. You trusted your intuition. And I am grateful.   And most importantly, thanks to the powers that "be". That brought these dynamic individuals into my life. It is through my interaction with your creations, that enabled me to get a better understanding of myself, the world and how we are intricately connected. When I look back and read each week, sometimes in no particular order, one lesson always reveals itself. That if we become willing partners in each other's success, good things happen to everyone involved in that effort. It is my sincerest hope, that I have given back to this experience, as much as I have received. -Best Regards, Robert J. Adams One of the Good Guys

item.title: Landing Page
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: My Commitment To You
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: Our commitment is to provide our audience a resource, based on personal experience, contributions and research, that will give our readers tools to achieve their professional goals through understanding and growth. By serving the entire community in various roles, responsibilities and skill levels, our aim is to provide a forum that will open and further discussions. Discussions that bring about positive change. Best Regards, Robert J. Adams

item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Ten years ago, I was at a crossroads with my career path. Tired of the office grind and leaving my work day with nothing more than a check, I knew something had to change. After taking some time to reflect and focus on what was important to me, I finally had a goal. My goal was to find a career path that would keep me engaged with the pubic, challenged my current skills  and encouraged the development of new skills. Job posting after job posting. Interview after interview, I wasn't finding what I was looking for. Sensing my frustration, that's when a friend  suggested I try promotional work. Say what? What's that? This is what she said....
  • I have the freedom to make my own schedule
  • My co-workers were diverse and fun
  • I'm always talking about the latest products at the most happening places around town.
  • Sometimes across the country.
  • Rarely are any two days at work the same.
'But is it legal?" was my next question. After doing some research, I tagged along with her to the next booking. I had to see this for myself.

The day I was introduced to event marketing, my life and career path would never be the same. And I am grateful for it.

Giving back to the people and industry, that has given me so much, is  the reason why this forum exists.

 When I decided to give this "promo" thing a try, ten years ago, there wasn't much guidance.

Luckily you've got a Good Guy on your side.

Originally from Cleveland, Ohio, Robert Adams has called Las Vegas Nevada his home for the past 8 years.  Raised by his grandparents in the restaurant industry, Robert learned customer service and face to face interaction skills early on in his life. After his United States Army and higher learning studies, Robert solidified his sales and management abilities in the automotive retail industry where he won numerous awards for customer satisfaction, product knowledge, and productivity. His experience and ability to solve complex challenges has translated into a rewarding career in the event marketing industry. Robert provides information and guidance , in a straight-forward manner, that reflects on both his successes and challenges within the event marketing industry.

item.title: Emily-Kate Niskey
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
When you hear  Emily-Kate's qualifications and skills in delivering memorable brand experiences, you'll be impressed. When you read her personal bio and approach to some incredible challenges, you'll be amazed. Every once in a while life presents the opportunity to meet seemingly ordinary people who do some extraordinary things. We are honored to present to our readers Emily-Kate Niskey.

I have been working in Events and Promotions for the past 9 years! I really do enjoy it, I like the diversity and I definitely love talking  people, you kind of have to in this business. Over the years, I have built relationships with clients who now use me on a regular basis. I have been working for the same company for CES for the past 5 years as a V.I.P. Hostess leading V.I.P. tours for very high-level executives of Fortune 500 companies as well as hosting their parties. I also work ConExpo for the same client every year.

 

    I always tell my kids to do any job, no matter how small with excellence because you never know who is watching and I am happy to be able to show them I am living proof of that. When I was a Brand Ambassador for a three-month promotion for Windows 8 and the New Surface Computer with GTE Events I quickly moved up to digital artist and was awarded a $700 bonus for being the best BA of this Nationwide program. I am also an assisted sales rep for Xbox One and was awarded an Xbox One as a bonus for selling the most Xbox Ones of the program as well as posting the most on our Microsoft Facebook Page and blogging about Xbox One!

   Besides my promo life, I am a wife and mother of three beautiful kids Gideon (7), Logan (14), and Julia (15). I am an artist and hold two masters degrees, one in Education (Curriculum Design and Instruction ) and Business (Organizational Psychology) . I have taught my own private art classes, painted murals, painted sets for TV shows, shot photos in the music industry and worked as a photojournalist. My husband and I have a web design, printing and software development company, a staffing agency as well as a catering business. Oh yeah, I am also a recent breast cancer survivor and blog author. http://myvigorlifestyle.com/blog/ During my recovery, I kept a book of my artwork. Soon to be published, I hope that it will inspire others who may be facing adversity. I think it is important to have multiple sources of income. It also keeps me busy. Many people, who are aware of my  master's degree of education, think I'm crazy for not making use of it. I kindly disagree with them. Most people, educated or not, don't enjoy their job as much as I do mine. -Emily-Kate Niskey

If your next event requires a reliable, charismatic, and professional brand experience specialist, look no further. Reach out to Emily-Kate today. Her direct contact information is below. - Robert J. Adams

Emily-Kate Niskey ekniskey@gmail.com Cell          702-666-2763
Home       702-629-6466
Google     214-293-5283

item.title: Good Friends
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: The Good Guys have been in the event marketing and trade show industry for almost a decade. Along the way, we have met some outstanding people who believe in the same core values that we do. We are proud to be associated with these groups, individuals and companies. They selflessly share their time, experience, and resources for the betterment of the industry and those who work in it. We encourage our readers to learn from these leaders representing diverse roles, responsibilities, and personal experiences.

item.title: Joshua Simi
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Joshua consistently demonstrates what it takes to be good at what he does and won't settle for being average.

 He always has an upbeat attitude, a smile on his face and a professional approach to every opportunity that is presented to him. He shows up early, works hard, and stays late to make sure the job is done right.

 Relatively new to experiential marketing, Joshua's work ethic is quickly building a great reputation with agencies across the country. He also strives to learn more about his craft and the world around him through both traditional and contemporary outlets. We are fortunate to have Joshua in the Las Vegas market and look forward to his future accomplishments.

Contact Information: joshsimi@live.com http://www.facebook.com/joshua.simi Physical Attributes: Weight-195 Height 6’4” Hair-Black Eyes-Brown Education: 1996-1998: Bonanza High School 1998-2000: Community College 2000-2002: CSN Professional Profile: Objective: My goal is to obtain a position as a brand ambassador. My experience and hard work will leave all parties with a positive experience as I not only represent myself, but the company with the utmost professionalism. I take great pride in my work because it’s a reflection of one's character. My past experience ranges from brand ambassador work, modeling, product specialist, guerrilla style marketing, and costume characters with team lead and management skills as well. Experience:

02/2014 Coca Cola

02/2014 CES Convention Sonic Emotion @ Las Vegas Convention Center

02/2014 Hooters @ Hooters Casino (Team Lead)

03/2014 M&M’s @ The Strip

03/2014 BMW @ The Aria Casino

04/2014 Dr. Pepper @ The Academy Country Music Awards

04/2014 Southern Wine and Spirits @ UNLVino Wine Event

item.title: Our goal is to help achieve yours.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
This blog is just the beginning of a much larger journey toward my goal. Taking the first step is met with both excitement and nervousness.  Nobody wants to fail. Especially in front of your friends, mentors, respected colleagues and peers. But the opportunity to leave a positive and lasting mark on the industry is completely worth the risk.

It is my sincere hope, that I can save someone from making the mistakes that I have made. However, the inspiration behind this forum, is the belief that you will take the success I've enjoyed to another level. By providing our audience, a forum to discuss topics affecting the industry and the role we play in our careers, we'll learn how to duplicate success together. We'll cover the basics for new "Good Guys & Girls" diving into the event marketing & trade show industry. The Good Guys are also dedicated to staying on top of current industry trends while also engaging the tough issues facing our evolving, fast-paced environment. Guest writers and industry leaders, from varying roles, will also stop by to lend their insight and expertise. I look forward to our partnership in professional development. By helping you achieve your goals, I'll be closer to achieving mine. Best Regards, Robert J. Adams

item.title: Change Is Coming. Where Do You Want Be When It Happens?
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
There are 3 things that make me proud about this blog. It provides a source of information for those who want to know more or become better within the industry. We strive to deliver an honest point of view that involves real world situations, rewards and challenges. What we're surprisingly most critical of is that the message is never rushed. If we don't feel excited to share whatever topic we've considered, bounced off of colleagues, or discussed within the Good Guys household, it doesn't get written. This recent brainstorming session was more challenging than in the past. Then the topic hit me and it was clear as day. All I had to do was take a look at what was happening around me. By being involved, in what some have remarked as a "philanthropic" hobby, I have come to be acquainted with people of action, intelligence, and desire. One thing I can assure you. We're embarking on an era of change and opportunity.The question is where do you want to be when it happens?

  Some people embrace change. Some people do not. Our current generation of event marketing professionals are equipped  with tools, knowledge and a growing sense of community, at the very least mutualism, to overcome any perceived adversity. Is this a ra ra session or a pat on the back for how far we've come? By no means. What I'd like to share with you is this. On your way to your work schedule's third gig in sixteen hours, change is happening. Pressing behind the wheel for hours to your tour's next stop? Change is happening. Being at the forefront of change gives us the unique ability to shape our futures as individuals and as an industry.  What would you like your future to look like?

 As I mentioned earlier, this post was completely inspired by my past week. Obviously I'm only one person. Is it fair to say that another professional in our line of work had a similar work week?. Listen closely to what I'm sharing or you might miss it . As luck would have it, I had a change in my booking schedule that gave me more free time than I'd like. Feeling a bit disappointed and lighter in the wallet, I sought my usual outposts of last-minute opportunities. My solo pity party didn't last long. I ran into my colleague and friend Jordan Roby, who offered words of encouragement. Even though her words came from the other side of the country, the timing was perfect. Her words kept me from spending too much time being unfocused.

 In Newton's First Law of Motion: "Any object that is set in motion tends to stay in motion until met by resistance." Or something of that nature. Edwin Goitia, from Promo Rockstars, and I have been sharing ideas for the past few months. His enthusiasm, common sense thinking, genuine desire to further the industry and the people within it rivals my own. I will concede, that when it comes to technology, he is Mr. Miagi and I'm Danielson. He effectively uses those tools to educate and inform his following.  He has graciously allowed me to contribute as an advisor during past "Hangouts". Last week I proudly co-hosted. The current topic is part of a three-part series discussing "Negotiations". We also enjoyed the luxury of having other respected industry leaders like Black Rose Agency's driving force and founder Anissa Campbell. Her expertise in managing a successful agency added another dynamic to the conversation. Next month Edwin will be offering his group's discussion on I-Tunes. Pretty exciting stuff. Our backgrounds, our personalities and how we deliver our messages are different. Our professional experiences have many similarities but the message and desire to contribute in making this industry great for all of us is the same.

 During our transition to WordPress and pursuing opportunities,  a young lady gave me a chance to strengthen my mentorship skills. She is not only new to the industry but also to Las Vegas. Understanding that she was embarking on a new path that included risks, she sought guidance via LinkedIn. I admit that I'm a LinkedIn skeptic. Mainly because 70 percent of LinkedIn's members use it incorrectly, in my opinion. This young lady got my typical reply to her "connect" request. The dialogue and tone of my correspondence weeds out popularity seekers. Strangely enough I have yet to get a second email, to build a real professional "connection" until she replied. Here's the link for your reference and enjoyment as to the contents of that message. Feel free to copy it. howtohownot.pdf  She was not discouraged by the tone of my words. She respected the value of my time and focus. I took note of her willingness to take another step by eloquently conveying her intentions. Over the past few weeks I've been able to answer some of her initial questions and dispel some common myths. I was also able to provide her some direction and tools that will enable her to get a quick start. She's inquisitive, tenacious and I'm excited to see where her drive takes her. Thinking back to when I started my career in this industry the tools available were cutting edge.  In today's George Jetson world, those same tools would be considered cutting edge to the Flintstones. The amount of information I was able to share with her over a few weeks easily took me a year to attain back then.  A year!

      Tomorrow I will be promoting "The High Roller" down at our new vibrant tourist spot "The Linq". This new Las Vegas attraction provides a Ferris wheel experience that is also the largest observation deck in the world. It's the buzz of the town. Tactical Media Group offered me this opportunity to handle the more than anticipated response. Being a latecomer to the already established team and the nature of what we do, information was unintentionally slow in reaching me for this event. No problem. I reached out on social media and bam. A young man and amazing hustler Joshua Simi was able and willing to provide all the information I needed to be prepared for the event. Here's another remarkable thought. I have never met Joshua in my life. With the technology ,social media and the integration of non social media outlets and sharing of ideas, I feel like I've known him for years.

  Winding down my day there's Alex Nguyen and Krystie Phannareth. Two industry colleagues that don't own an alarm clock because they never go to sleep. They are part  of the driving force that has consistently given to the betterment of our professions future. By delivering daily tools to newbies and advocating on behalf of those who don't know where to turn for answers, I've witnessed their efforts restore a companies good name against slander. I've also seen their efforts correct payment issues. Pro agency or pro staff? To me, they are pro "industry". They both work gigs outside of these forums so the time in the forums is nowhere near their daily rates if compensated at all.

 To tie it all together, this what I gathered from my past ten days. We exist in a time and a community of determined problem solvers, who embrace technology and disregard subscribing to over inflated egos for the betterment of those who want to "do", "have" and "be" more. Never has our industry had the resources to bring together people from different backgrounds and from the furthest corners of the country to deliver the same message. What do YOU want to HAVE, BE, and DO when the positive and dedicated efforts of a few help  shape the next era of exciting opportunities and change in the experiential marketing industry?

item.title: Job Description & Dynamics. Executive Producers. A Tour Manager's Greatest Resource.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
David Haas ExecutiveProducer/Managing Partner- Synertia 

[su_quote cite="Robert J. Adams"]The jovial looking gentleman pictured is the man I call when I've run out of answers.  As an Executive Producer, Dave and I have worked on some remarkable projects over the past 8 years. Dave brings to the table an unmeasurable amount of experiences. What sets him apart from his colleagues is his "let's find a way" attitude and road experience.  A huge blessing to someone who hadn't seen it all when we first met.  This week the Good Guys are grateful to have Dave as our  guest contributor.[/su_quote]

So in the course of becoming a tour manager, you've already made it past a couple of hurdles.  Your resume has gotten past the gatekeeper. You've cleared the HR hurdle and have been passed along to the Account Management team. They obviously like you, really, what’s not to like! Your paperwork checks out and you are a go. Now what? For the lucky tour managers, you are brought in before any crew, before the program is scheduled to leave the shop. For the unlucky, you meet your new team at the first load in having never unloaded the trucks or built the set before. Regardless of which side of the spectrum you happen to land on, hopefully one thing is constant; you are working with a great executive producer.

Before we dive into that relationship, let’s look at experiential marketing agencies for a lay of the land.  Experiential agencies function like any other company.  These agencies have senior leadership to manage business operations and functional groups like accounting, payroll, and human resources.  Experiential agencies have account or project management groups that manage the needs of their clients.  Then there are the creative folks who design, illustrate, and proof all the creative artwork on behalf of the client brand.  Finally, there is production and operations.  Production management brings the client’s program to life by building the trucks, sets, and experiences that you, the Tour Manager, and your team will manage while on the road.    

Before we dive into that relationship, let’s look at experiential marketing agencies for a lay of the land.  Experiential agencies function like any other company.  These agencies have senior leadership to manage business operations and functional groups like accounting, payroll, and human resources.  Experiential agencies have account or project management groups that manage the needs of their clients.  Then there are the creative folks who design, illustrate, and proof all the creative artwork on behalf of the client brand.  Finally, there is production and operations.  Production management brings the client’s program to life by building the trucks, sets, and experiences that you, the Tour Manager, and your team will manage while on the road.    

The relationship between you, the Tour Manager, and your Executive Producer is a special one. If he or she does their job well, you and your team will reap great benefits. If not, you’ll be the first to know. In most cases, the Executive Producer started out just like you, working the front line as a Brand Ambassador then moving on to Tour Manager.  Sadly, some Producers have never seen the road or have only seen it through the eyes of Account Management. Take every opportunity to learn from your Executive Producer. Be an active listener. Be a proactive manager. Work with your Executive Producer as a teammate. This relationship is built on trust. Trust that you will maintain the integrity of the client’s brand and the set or experience and trust that the Executive Producer will support you when things get rough. 

Long before you were hired, the entire Agency was winning this piece of business that you are now managing.  The client liked the agency’s ideas so much that an experiential marketing tour was born.  Someone had to build this program.  In doing so, the Executive Producer tapped into his network of fabricators, vendors, partners, and contractors to bring you your program.  Some programs can be built in 2-4 weeks; others take 4-6 months.

In building your program, the Executive Producer figured out how to, not only build great set pieces, but also how to have them travel safely from market to market.  There’s a case for everything, not just blankets and duct tape.  The truck pack has been well thought out and then tried three different ways just to be sure.  Your Producer has stocked a tool or gig box with all the tools and gadgets that you might ever need or want.  It’s the attention to these details that will make your experience as a tour manager better than having a Producer that just pushes you and program out the door. 

 Every stop on your tour is an opportunity for new consumers to see your event set for the first time.  As the Tour Manager, not only are you responsible for running great events, but also for keeping the event materials presentable for the next city or show.  Normal wear and tear are expected, but making sure the event materials last is an important part of the job, so embrace it.

As Tour Manager, you are the eyes and ears of the Agency that has hired you.  Your team and the Brand Ambassadors that you manage are the face and voice of the brand.  That’s a big responsibility.  Again, embrace it.  Your Account team and Executive Producer have put quite a bit of responsibility into your lap.  How you take the reins will chart your course for the program as well as for your further endeavors in the business.  It’s an unwritten rule, but you're only as good as your last event.

item.title: "Networking" vs. a "Working Net"
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
So you have 900 "connections" on LinkedIn, 8,000 "followers" on Twitter and 1500 "friends" on FaceBook.

In your mind, you're networking, but is your net really working? Is the amount of effort you spend collecting contacts equal to your desired results? If the answer is yes then congrats. You're probably not reading this. Instead, you're getting ready for your photo shoot for the cover of Forbes, GQ, or Time Magazine. If the answer is no, then sorry. No photo shoot or interviews for you so keep reading.  Networking started out as a buzzword about 20 years ago.

Like all chic terms, networking came about as a word describing a groundbreaking and innovative change to a culture's way of doing things that produced results. Nowadays the word networking is an overused word that sounds more like a nightclub. If you're not in it or doing it then you're not cool, savvy, or a professional.

In the Good Guys eyes, networking is a nightclub where the drinks are expensive, most people are fakers or takers, and you can't hear a damn word anybody is saying. Want to know if you have a working net and not just a database of names?

Here's a challenge. Go to any one of your social media pages that you consider your black book of opportunities. Now randomly choose any 10 of your "network" contacts. Blindfold yourself, scroll while you count to 5, throw darts at a printed list, whatever. Got your list? Good. Now I want you to be honest with yourself. It is only by being honest in this challenge that you'll learn, become better, and create more opportunities to earn money in the event marketing industry. Next, ask yourself these questions regarding each one of your ten contacts. 1. If you called, messaged or emailed them today, how quickly would they recognize your voice or your name? 2. Are they a 1st contact or just a contact of a contact? In other words. Do they know you or of you, what you do, or past projects. 3. If they held the keys to an opportunity that you desired and were qualified for, what would you think you're chances would be of landing that opportunity or at the very least an interview? 4. If you held the keys to an opportunity that they'd be interested in and were qualified for, how inclined would you be to refer it to them? Pretty crazy stuff huh? The writing is on the wall and it's time to start making some changes. If you keep doing what you've been doing, you're going to get what you've always gotten.  Don't worry though. All is not lost. As in any recovery process, the first step is the admission. Now I want you to admit to yourself...."This networking thing sucks. It is not producing the results that I would like it to. I don't want to be in a high school popularity contest, I want to have more opportunities to make money. I want a working net." Step two. Purge. Yep, purge. Use the four questions above as your filter. If they can't be qualified by any one of the four questions then "unfriend", "un-follow" and "disconnect".

I'd rather have 200 mutually benefiting business relationships than 900 "friends". You'll also enjoy having freed up your feeds so that you can focus on further developing the relationships that you already have. Step three. If you're not ready to purge them then you better be prepared to start putting forth some action with that contact so that they do fall within that criteria. Step four. Develop a follow-up system for your remaining contacts. Out of sight. Out of mind. A Key part of having contacts is actually contacting them. Weird right?

There are several tools and services available that makes reaching out to people I've met in the industry a relatively easy task. Some paid services like Constant Contact make follow-up a breeze. It's an investment, but time is money. Free services like Google Circles allows me to group email my working net. Step five. The content of communication. Know what you're going to say to your contact before you say it. Have a reason for contacting them. "Hey do you have any tours or gigs coming up" is old and comes off disingenuous and quite frankly it is.

Because I tour so much, I often inform my working net when I have finished a project so that they know I'm available. Big difference. Or I'll ask them permission to directly send them my updated resume.  This avoids the "fill out the profile and we'll add you to our database" spiel. Not that you won't still have to do that but you'll also have an opportunity for your contact to see your work first hand without being clumped together with other candidates. Step six. Focus on developing meaningful relationships. The event marketing world is comprised of some very awesomely unique and colorful individuals.

Step out of your comfort zone and actually get to know your colleagues. Your genuine desire to know your colleagues and key holders can lead to useful knowledge or opportunities. Maybe not today but you'll want opportunities presented to you down the road too. Last. Step seven. Be a resource. By no means am I saying give away an inside track to a limited opportunity that you also want. For example...a project calls for one MC and you're an MC.

It might sound selfish but you have to take care of yourself and your responsibilities first.

What I am saying is if I hear of an opportunity that is not limited or that I might not be qualified/available for then I'm handing out paychecks.

I can honestly say that Ryan and I have handed out more money than we have ever made for ourselves. 

Make sure that the folks you refer opportunities to best represent you. People will remember you when the shoe is on the other foot. If they don't then you may want to consider if they are in your network or your working net.

item.title: How to Get Your First Tour.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
"I see a lot of tour manager and assistant tour manager jobs available but all want previous tour managing experience. Thus, my question is how do you get that experience if you need it first?" 
First of all I'd like to thank the individual who took the initiative to ask this question. It wouldn't have been so remarkable if they hadn't asked this question in a forum of event marketing ninjas. I tip my hat to you for your desire to be better regardless of what others may or may not think.

    9 years ago I was facing the same challenge.

I had tons of interviews but no offers.

Couple things you need to understand........

  •     This is a HIGHLY competitive industry filled with plenty of not just good but exceptional tour managers.
Whatever position or role you're in now, do it to the best of your ability. Find ways to make yourself a commodity that is in demand. Doctors and lawyers are professionals who go to school for years before they are tested and licensed.

Do you think they stop educating themselves just because they have a prestigious piece of paper?

Absolutely not.

Professionals in every industry consistently, and in my case constantly, thrive for knowledge to separate themselves from the pack.
  •   When you least expect it, someone influential in this industry is watching. It could be your boss, client, another agency etc. If you don't lose sight of this fact, someone will be there during your shining moment. Forget it and they might catch you when the moment is not so shiny.

   In this day of social networking, versus a handshake, face-to-face meeting or a phone call, it's not only whom you know, but how well do you know them?

Name dropping won't work anymore.

Focus on creating meaningful relationships. Knowing a person's birthday used to be a big deal in the past. Thanks to technology that tool of thoughtfulness and genuine interest has been devalued significantly. Find positive and useful information about a gatekeeper that can't be found on your favorite social media site.
  • There's always an opportunity. Keep in mind that everyone wants a job, at least the professionals in my circle do.
  • Decision makers and key holders are constantly being badgered for jobs. Be prepared to offer something in return for their influence or advice.
Stand out and don't be one of the thousands of "fakers & takers" in this business. No matter how small or insignificant the offering may seem to you, the recipient may find value.

True Story

Recently I missed out on an opportunity  to work a convention. Instead of crying how qualified I was or how much money I missed, my fellow Good Guy Ryan and I decided to offer a concierge service to our hardworking colleagues and agencies working the convention that day. I wasn’t doing anything else. I had time to run errands or help those who were working  that needed a hand.

What was the harm right?

The gift we received was immeasurable.

Phone calls, emails and social media posts of appreciation surrounded us. Work is more than just a check. It’s a level of accomplishment and appreciation for your efforts and body of work. That day was a special day. The response made us proud of who we are and reaffirmed the value of our mission. Your generous gesture will be appreciated if it is genuine. Give without expecting anything in return.
  •  You gotta have a little luck, persistence and a sense of humor in getting your first break.
The account manager that hired me for my 1st tour manager position just had blind faith in me. We had complete chemistry in the interview. It also helped that I had a strong Sr. Tour Manager that I had never met, joining me on the program. Although she is no longer in the industry, I consider her a friend and great sounding board for my ideas to this day.
  •  Reduce the risk of hiring you.
The truth is that before you're able to list the coveted "Tour Manager" title on your resume, you are a risk because you don't have a track record. Strange as it may sound, there are people in this industry who have some bad history and still get work. How is that possible? People in this industry talk. It is a very small world. We all have strengths and weaknesses. Good habits and bad ones. I once recommended a person for a tour that had a spotty track record that wasn't related to the nature of the new opportunity. I knew the person would do a great job under these new circumstances because I was aware of their strengths and weaknesses based on their history. Account managers know that bad things are going to happen on the road. It's not an "if" but a "when". Presenting yourself in a light that minimizes common risk factors allows decision makers to rationalize making you their candidate. Before I got my break, I helped my buddy with his furniture company delivering on weekends for extra cash.

Guess what the delivery vehicle was?

A 26 ft box truck, the mule and preferred vehicle of the industry.

Even though I had never been a tour manager, I was able to list a crucial skill.

  •   Watch The Karate Kid or Rudy at least 100 times....lol.
Believe in yourself and your abilities. Account managers are people just like you and I. Underdogs and long shots, we all love them. Just turn on the NCAA tournament and see for yourself. Someone will have the money to bet on the dark horse to win big. Just keep applying and maintain a level of unique professionalism.

 Someone will find you if you stay the course.

Until then good luck.

item.title: Is it time to unionize? Part 1
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Higher pay. Health coverage. Equal compensation. Legal representation. Shorter payment cycles. For brand ambassadors across the country, these are only a few issues that has fueled the union conversation. What would it take to unionize? What would each side give up? Who wins? Who loses? Is there a compromise? A conversation that cannot be ignored as we all have something at stake. If history has taught us anything, ignoring a social issue doesn't make it go away. Generally we introduce topics that we are well versed in or have invested research to discuss. This week we're stepping out of our comfort zone by introducing a topic that we know very little about. In order to preserve the point of view of someone with general knowledge, the integrity of the subject, and bring about engaging dialogue, we have done zero if any research. If that sounds strange to you, it does to us too. We're going to try it anyways. The question that is being asked more and more often, is it time to unionize?  When I think of unions, I think of the United Auto Workers, the Teamsters, and United Food and Commercial Workers Unions to name a few. Organizations that  represent trades and professions that were affected by morally and socially challenging times in America. Women's suffrage, prohibition, organized crime, child labor abuses, the Great Depression, Civil Rights and war were just some of the barbershop and dinner topics of choice. Every era has their struggles. We have our own present day challenges but do they compare to the era when these unions were formed? I would say no. So just because things are better today than they were yesterday does that mean we should stop pursuing better working terms and conditions? Do we work in an industry where our business partners always have our best interest as the top priority. To that I also say no, but proceed with caution and be careful what you wish for. The very thing  that we think we want may have more negative than positive consequences. What do unions potentially bring to the table? Leverage. Unions get their power in two parts. The first part is a simple concept. That concept is sheer numbers. By amassing a membership of significant volume, a union is fundamentally born. The more members, the greater its ability to enact its agenda or purpose. The second part of a union's power comes from solidarity. Getting everybody, or at least a majority, to agree on issues and the order of these issues importance is sometimes easier said than done. However, when an issue and the hierarchy of importance has been established, things start moving.

 What are we giving up by being in a union? Well first there are dues. We don't get something for nothing right? What those dues would be in dollars and cents, I haven't the foggiest idea. I imagine the larger the union, the smaller the dues. This is why some unions piggy back on larger unions until their numbers make more financial sense. In the meantime, the group hitching the ride on the larger group probably has very little say on agendas or their importance.

 Individuality. By belonging to a union we must be willing to conform, basically giving up any flexibility of being an independent contractor in the event marketing industry. We'd be putting complete faith in an infrastructure that, for the most part, fundamentally represents what we want individually. An equal amount of what we consider"fair" by means of asking for more and better from the other side. Notice I said "for the most part". Ever disagree with a friend or significant other?  Talk about a loaded question. There will be times that we may not agree with a particular issue collectively. Of course, we'll have opportunities to have our voice be heard by vote. But once that vote has been finalized we are bound to stand united behind the results, essentially focusing the union's power, solidarity. Standardization. Depending on where you fall on the coin of standardization, it can be a good thing or a bad thing. The truth of the matter is that there are some folks out there that are doing pretty well for themselves as brand ambassadors just the way things are. Now when I say brand ambassadors, I'm also including street teamers, promotional models, product specialists and any of the many variations. Those who consistently find work on projects that pay $25 - $40 per hour could potentially be shooting themselves in the foot by unionizing. The flip side is that we could potentially rid ourselves of the $15 per hour posts of the past decade. This surely will be an issue now that the state of Washington has raised its minimum wage to $15 per hour. Who wants to work for minimum wage? I sure as hell don't. These are just some of the issues and questions we need to ask ourselves before pressing onward. Join me next time as we discuss what we perceive to be some agency challenge and reactions to a brand ambassador's union. [polldaddy poll=8158500]

item.title: Is it time to unionize ? Part 2.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
In part 1 of this growing topic, we introduced the possibility of unionizing the event market industry and all of its kin. Since that last post, I've had several conversations with recognized and respected professionals throughout the country who shared their take on the subject. Although we all don't agree on some issues and potential outcomes of such a structure, we all agree that there needs to be a change. Some change has already taken place. Whatever the future holds, we're sure to see some significant departures from "business as usual". But is unionizing the answer? Come join the discussion as we evaluate the future and what it could potentially mean to you and your career. As I had alluded to earlier, as the conversation has gained popularity, those who are active within the industry has weighed in on the subject. In order to assess all the moving parts of organizing a union and its sustainability into the future, we first had to identify why the subject was gaining momentum. What I took away from those conversations was insightful. I also noticed that there were certain grievances that provided more fuel to the unionization argument than others. No matter what market or branch of the industry, the same issues were reoccurring. Let's take a look at what these issues are and how they affect the men and women who are in the trenches. Long turn around or late payments for work performed. Besides road team members and day to day operations personnel, I remember a time in the industry where you never saw a check before 90 days after completing a project. Financially, a slow month or transitioning to  event marketing with that pay circle was scary. Fortunately, most agencies have come to their senses and do their best to have their checks sent out every two weeks or at the very least bi-monthly. However, there are a few agencies out there that are still on a 90 day turn around. A recipe for the brand ambassador blues is sure to hit social media when an independent contractor doesn't fully read the agency's pay policy with a 90 day turnaround. Throw in the possibility of  a late payment from the agency's client and the villagers are storming the castle. Late payments are extremely rare, but when they do occur it  seems to be at the worst possible times.  Car payment due, vacation, an upcoming birthday celebration, etc. I see this area as being the biggest canvass for unions to provide member value                      .

Higher pay rates. There are so many ways that this conversation can be framed that I've decided to give "pay rate' its own forum for future discussion. Knowing what or who is worth, as a defined value, is another tough task. Everyone deserves to be paid a fair wage for a fair days work. Agencies, staff, support team members and account mangers and anyone else that has lent their skill or time to a project have earned a check. With the pie being only so big, there are only so many slices. If an independent contractor doesn't like the proposed pay rate from the booking agent, he or she is not obligated to accept the terms. That's the simple side of the financial piece of any project. The challenging side is fitting other pieces like project budget and other project related expenses. Two identical programs could leave the same facilitating company and have different profit and cost margins. Crazy stuff isn't it? Enter the state of Washington and their highly publicized minimum wage changes. Now you have a series of circumstances that requires careful legal maneuvering. This is potentially another area that a union could provide clarity and provide member value. I'm curious to see what if any tools would be utilized by a union to bring about pay rate changes. Standardization?  Independent contractors are unique in skill sets, education, and experience. Just as unique are some of the projects that are executed. Determining a standard rate under these variables would give me day mares.

Health coverage & retirement benefits. Folks who have chosen event marketing as a career work just as hard as any factory employee while possessing the business savvy and people skills of a Texas attorney. So it only makes sense that the soldiers in the field should be offered the same type of benefits offered to those who work a 9-5. While the show must go on, people do get sick in our line of work. No lie. We do. We also like the idea of maintaining our health through routine doctor, dentists and eye exams. Imagine that?! As rugged and durable as we are demanded to be, dismissing the importance of these benefits puts our long term health at a high risk. With the introduction of Obama Care and the adoption of W2 vs 1099 tax recording practices by marketing firms, most of us are left scratching our heads. Why are we not offered these same resources and what can we do about it? Could a union cut the red tape and lead us to a path of better health and get us these benefits?

Enforcement of state and local labor laws. Labor laws are inadvertently overlooked every day in our line of work. It happens by accident and devoid of any malicious intent. The oversight happens out of plain lack of knowledge. The executing company is based in Florida while the traveling team is setting up in New York. A union, especially a local chapter, could provide useful information that could assist in bringing consistency and compliance to a fluid operation. We can all agree that America is the greatest country on the planet. The two edge sword of living in America is that each of the 50 states has the right to create laws that suit their geographical and ideological needs. As a result, what is a legal business practice in one state might not be legal in another. Labor laws encompassing hours of service and "employee" breaks is a perfect example. In some states workers are required to take a documented break. In some states that break must be compensated. In that same state, the break is not required to be a paid break if the break lasts more than an hour or if the employee leaves the functioning work radius of operation. Being aware of labor law changes and exceptions, from state to state, sounds like a full time job.

Next time......The Good Guys will close out the unionization discussion with our 3rd installment. We'll evaluate potential unforeseen outcomes as a result of organizing our profession.  We'll also outline what key factors and events that need to take place in order to make it a reality. We welcome diverse perspectives, so please feel free to email us your thoughts or comment on any topic related post. Also stop by the "Good Guy of the Month page to see who the trendsetters, go getters, and leaders of the industry are. Until we meet again my friends.....Don't just be average. Be Good!

item.title: Is it time to unionize ? Final Part 3.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
My pursuit to find answers to this question has been both educational and at times , difficult. Difficult in a sense that I changed my stance as I discovered new information. In order to be objective and let you, our readers form your own opinion, my goal was to focus on just the facts.  As I became more involved with this project I started to form my own opinion. Then I had to take a step back and ask myself an even bigger question. Is a union for the event marketing industry even possible? Of course, anything is possible but is it possible under the current climate? Forget having all the pieces in place. Are there any pieces? Is there a driving force and if so who's behind it? My answer my may surprise you......

Just like you, I love the event marketing industry. I couldn't imagine leaving this industry  and going back to my previous profession or take on a new career path. However, you and I represent a small minority. As I look around, the staff is getting younger. Not only because I'm getting older but because the  talent pool that once was, has moved on. Maybe they started a family. Perhaps they finally landed a job in the field of their college studies. Maybe the ups and downs of our industry just wore them out and decided to find something more stable. What I have found is that most of the people I speak to in event marketing are here until something better comes along or until something in their personal life  changes. This is where our profession significantly departs from professions that are successfully unionized. Autoworkers, teamsters, carpenters, bricklayers, teachers, law enforcement, plumbers, flight attendants, food workers, railroad, are unions made up of workers who are long-term if not lifers. The company that they work for may change  but their line of work does not.

By the numbers. Here are a few numbers that should be considered. In 2013, there were 14.5 million members in the U.S., compared with 17.7 million in 1983. In 2013, the percentage of workers belonging to a union in the United States (or total labor union compared to 20.1% in 1983.  Of that 11.3%, 36% was in the public sector  while the private sector was only 7.6%.What demographic group do you think we belong in? Is the picture becoming clearer?

Talk is cheap. There isn't a day that goes by that the "union" word isn't brought up. It's usually accompanied by plenty of "it would be nice" , "there should be" or "we should". Don't misunderstand what I'm about to say. There are great people in our industry. Hard-working, intelligent, honest, good people whom I respect immensely. There are however very few leaders in the industry that possess the drive, discipline, and character to initiate a union forming process. The few that do possess these qualities are pursuing other opportunities and the rest would lose under the formation of a union. Am I being negative? I don't think so. Don't believe me? For as many times as I've heard people talk about forming a union in the past two years I have yet to hear a single person say these words...."I'm going to....","I have started..." or "My next step is.." anywhere near the word union. I looked into the framework of unionization out of curiosity. It was mind numbing Are unions dead? In the United States there is a steady decline, especially among those who are under the age of 35. However, in Bangladesh, where work conditions are reminiscent of the US in the early 40's and 50's, unions are steadily thriving. I would expect that once that part of the world reaches fair working conditions and some level equality, unions may have served their purpose and then diminish there as well. Feel like you just had a history lesson? Me too. Let's look to the future. I personally don't think we need a union. We're far from being a third world country like Bangladesh and many years removed from the poor working conditions seen in the 40's and 50's. In addition, I don't see a leader currently available to champion the cause. Lastly, even if a union was formed, the people who would benefit from its inception will most likely have moved on or up from the industry.   All doom and gloom huh Robert?         We have to settle for the same one-sided negotiations without the promise of a better tomorrow? Step away from the ledge folks. It's going to be alright. With the help of social media and the incorporation of a free-flowing idea sharing culture, witnessed in many agency offices, information is moving quickly. Ideas are being exchanged. For example, today I had some fun back and forth banter with an account manager on a popular industry FB page.  By looking at these illustrations you can imagine how the conversation went. Although the joking was all in good fun, we were able to subtly communicate  what was happening in the jungle. Such dialogue was never imaginable a few years ago. What I'm trying to get at ladies and gentlemen is that I could foresee an arbitration entity coming to life before the formation of any union. I imagine it would be composed of talent and agency representatives alike. I also see an open forum as the stage. A very public place where the most valuable assets are at stake, reputations.

What makes this a more viable option than a union? For starters, the operating cost would be far less than a union. Both parties would have a clearer voice in  discussions instead of corporate suits delivering diluted versions of each others agendas.

Why would any agency ever go for such an idea? With all the expenses and challenges that goes with owning a business, the last thing industry owners would want is to accrue more expenses. Functioning or having a member on an arbitration board has a certain level of prestige that could potentially bolster their value with potential clients. And of course there's the advantage of being at the forefront of industry issues and challenges. Serving on a governing body like this puts participants at a distinct advantage over their peers. Probably to the extent that the positions would need to have a rotation to maintain integrity and fairness. Getting ahead of myself there. The point is that there are many incentives for our partners in business to be involved in this type of process.

I know we all work hard ladies and gentlemen. There are things that are not perfect with our industry that need to be changed. We  are also entitled  to a standard of living that rewards hard  work measurably better than those who came before us. Also understand that business owners have invested their hopes and countless hours in pursuing their goal of being an agency owner. They stand to lose the most. Some have probably borrowed money from a relative or mortgaged their home to make it a reality. Therefore, it makes sense that they be able to enjoy all the benefits that comes with that type of responsibility.  In order for both sides to grow and prosper, all possibilities should be considered before handing over a chance to work face to face or keyboard to keyboard. A solution to our grievances that serves each side fairly can be achieved through, organization, patience, mutual respect and communication. We're in the event marketing industry. We've never failed to face a challenge and there hasn't been a problem we haven't solved.

Wikipedia/International Labour Organization

Bureau of Labor Statistics (January 28, 2009). "Union members in 2008". Washington, D.C.: U.S. Department of Labor. Greenhouse, Steven (January 28, 2009). "Union membership up sharply in 2008, report says". The New York Times. p. A18. Whoriskey, Peter (January 29, 2009). "American union ranks grow after 'bottoming out'; first significant increase in 25 years". The Washington Post. p. A8.

item.title: Krystie Phannareth
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Krystie is one of my favorite people who I have never met in person. To say that her reputation precedes her is an understatement. She is known throughout the event marketing industry as an intelligent, hard-working, professional. She's proven time and time again that she's much more than just a pretty face. She's a major contributor who participates in the role of administrator for many trusted social media resource groups. In the virtual world  or out in the field, it's hard to find a place that Krystie has not left her influential mark. The Good Guys are grateful to be associated with such a consummate professional and trendsetter.

-Robert J. Adams

Krystie is an extremely experienced promotional and trade show associate. She has worked as an event manager, automotive product specialist, technology specialist, spokesmodel, emcee, crowd gather, booth associate and social media strategist. She possesses 18 years of experience in the experiential marketing industry and has represented numerous companies and products throughout industries such as high-tech, pharmaceutical, food / beverage, fashion, and automotive. In addition to her experience, Krystie is outgoing, professional, articulate and a hard worker. She dedicates herself to each and every booking to ensure success in her role. With her experience and "can do" attitude she is sure to be an asset to your next event!

Krystie Phannareth 704-726-6053

item.title: Edwin J. Goitia
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: Long  before I ever spoke with Edwin J. Goitia, I had concerns about the future of independent contractors and the future of the event industry. Who would lead, teach and encourage the next generation of brand ambassadors, trade show models and road warriors to accomplish more? Our first phone conversation, which lasted almost an hour, quickly put those concerns to rest. Our mutual desire, for our audiences' success, has been a great source of support and knowledge in accomplishing our goals                        Since 2010, Super Promotional Rockstars was created in order to streamline the process of professionalism in the industry and to help others succeed in a timely fashion, all while being provided the right training resources, education and networking platform in order to create the right success in the field.
