item.title: Mobile Tours. Are You Built for the Road?
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
When I started in this industry nine years ago, I was amazed by the opportunities that surrounded me in  my new-found profession.

Beginning my journey as a brand ambassador, I was meeting great people, enjoying the freedom of choosing projects, and basically making my schedule.

Then my whole world changed when I learned about touring.

The thought that a company would give me a paycheck, pay for my food and put me up in hotels as I traveled the country like a rock star seemed too good to be true.

I rarely use the word giddy but believe me, I was giddy!

As I scale down my road career and prepare to hand the keys over to the next generation of professionals, I feel obligated  to share with you what I've learned. The ups and downs of life on the road...

 There is not quite another experience like being a part of a mobile tour. The people I've met, the places I've gone and the things I've seen have left me eternally grateful that I fell into such an opportunity. If you want a work environment that offers rewarding challenges and adventure, touring might be for you. Here are a few things you should know before you start packing your bags and begin applying for mobile programs.

[su_animate type="bounceInDown" duration="2" delay="1"]SOLO TOUR [/su_animate] vs. [su_animate type="fadeInRightBig" duration="2" delay="1.5"]TEAM TOUR[/su_animate]

Each tour structure has its own advantages and challenges. Be wise and consider your personality before committing to a program. Being honest with yourself you can avoid some drama and enjoy a successful tour. Solo tours are great in the regard that the only person that you need to manage and take care of is you. If you want to eat at a certain time or place? You can. Want to run a few errands or take in some sightseeing on your down time? No problem, just go.

The drawback is that win, lose or draw, it's you vs. the world.

Long drives also have a tendency to add a level of awkwardness if you're not accustomed to keeping your mind engaged. Team tours obviously present a completely different dynamic. No matter what your role and responsibility within the program, being considerate and empathetic will serve you greatly. You're being teamed together with a person you most likely won't know. You might even have to share the same hotel room.

Talk about a potential reality show.

By being respectful, willing to learn your teammates thought processes and appreciating any differences, team tours offer a level of camaraderie that lasts beyond the program. "There's no ruby-red slippers Dorothy"
  For your first tour start small. Sixty days most. You'd be amazed by the things you might find yourself missing about home. Home cooked meals, your bed, favorite pet, the view from your favorite room in the house are a few small things you have to consider doing without for a while.

Not to mention the bigger things like your family and friends.

Luckily social media and advancements in technology have made staying in contact with those who are important to us manageable during the journey. Have an insecure significant other? You can kiss that relationship bye, bye, bye.
 [su_spacer]One of the great advantages of touring is the chance to vastly expand your personal and professional experiences.
[su_spacer]I've learned a lot about myself by being in  this trade.
[su_spacer]
The best rewards of all have been the friendships and relationships created that last still to this day.[su_spacer]
My inner circle is composed of great people who I met on the road. I can't imagine how different my life would be without them.[su_spacer]
[su_spacer]A band of brothers and sisters like no other.
 [su_spacer]The United States is a beautiful place. With the view from your office window being the entire country, no swank high-rise could ever compare.
[su_spacer]
Bring a good camera because you'll want to catch every scene and moment that others won't believe happened.[su_spacer]
[su_spacer]No tellin' what you'll see.
Feast or Fast Food
Maintaining healthy eating habits can be a tricky task on the road.[su_spacer]
Time, storage of items you'd usually eat and available dining options has claimed the regiments of the most disciplined road warriors.[su_spacer]
Traveling also gives you an opportunity to taste the best dishes the country has to offer. From crab legs in San Francisco, bbq in Memphis, etouffee in New Orleans to steaks in San Antonio, consider yourself an honorary member of the Food Network.[su_spacer]
You're a Star. Just Not in a Rap or Rock Kinda Way[su_spacer]
Money is hitting your bank account consistently and accumulating commas.[su_spacer]
You're in a different city every week if not every day, meeting interesting people from diverse backgrounds.[su_spacer]
Life is pretty good.[su_spacer]
This is a scenario that requires an occasional reality check.[su_spacer]
It's great to enjoy the financial freedom that touring provides.[su_spacer]
Not having to constantly look for gigs provides a certain sense of security.[su_spacer]
You work hard and deserve to reward yourself but realize the tour is eventually going to end and so are the checks.[su_spacer]

Like Uncle Ben Told Peter Parker.  "With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility."

Mobile programs offer an unbelievable amount of freedom in some ways and an enormous amount of commitment in others.
  • There are no sick days on the road.[su_spacer]
  • Your account manager and the brand you're representing expects you to execute every event at a high level. I have witnessed many tour managers, including myself, work under and through circumstances that would send a majority of the workforce running to their mommas.[su_spacer]
  • Get used to the idea of being on-call 24/7. With the home office being many miles away, solutions to unconventional challenges begin with your ability to assess situations, gather resources and prepare a plan of action. The best road staff are favorably compensated and rewarded with future opportunities by maintaining their composure and ability to solve problems with minimal supervision if any.[su_spacer]
 The upside of being many miles away from the home office is having the freedom to work in a virtually scrutiny free environment.[su_spacer]
Like a head coach of a professional sports team, you get a chance to put your personal stamp on a program. Being a part of a successful mobile program is a badge of honor.[su_spacer]
Those within the industry realize some of the challenges that mobile tours can present. They also know some of the qualities one must have to execute and be a part of a successful program.[su_spacer]
Nine years later, I reflect and have a sense of accomplishment for programs and people I've been associated with.  By providing some insight into the mobile side of experiential marketing, I hope that you will find the same sense of pride and satisfaction that I have.[su_spacer]

item.title: Professionally Unique. Standing Out From The Competition.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
[su_dropcap size="2"]T[/su_dropcap]his week we asked our readers to choose today's post. The people have spoken.  As always, thank you for your support and feedback.[su_spacer size="40"]

 My thought is that our loyal fans and colleagues chose this subject for a number of reasons.  The first that comes to mind is that, like most professionals, they want to find ways to better themselves in the event marketing industry. They understand the investment and rewards that come with consistent learning. My next thought is that these professionals realize the event marketing world and all its opportunities is no longer a secret. More and more people are finding out where the party is and some feel that the house is getting crowded.

 Being a professional is something to be proud of but is it enough? I say no. The reality is that I am meeting more top-notch professionals not only across the country but even in my home market of Las Vegas. In the past, doing all the right things a professional would do was enough to solidify being the first call for opportunities. This is no longer the case. You need to stand out, even among the upper level of our colleagues. But how? [caption id="attachment_505" align="alignright" width="248"] Las Vegas Star[/caption]
 
 Before we make our way to the deep side of the pool, let me share a few things with you. Embrace competition. I know not everyone in this industry has a competitive nature. The word competition incites thoughts of a "do whatever it takes to win" mentality involving underhandedness, lying, cheating, and stealing. We can thank those who got caught doing wrong, in all walks and professions, in the name of competition for this false ideology. Not everyone starts out being a "Good Guy". I didn't. The truth is that without competition the bad continue to exist and the average don't get any better.  If you're reading this I know that you don't want any part of that world. It's only through competition that we drive ourselves to be better and grow. For those who don't like the thought of competing, guess what? Your inception was a result of a competition. The odds of you being alive here today were lottery-esque at best. You've been competing even before you were born and look who won! 
 
Now let's move on to some ways you can be professionally unique...
 
1. Say Thank You: Pretty simple right? I send a thank you email to anybody that has put an opportunity in front of me. Talent coordinators, account executives and colleagues. When do I send a thank you email? After first contact. If I get the opportunity. After I've completed the project and If I don't get the opportunity. Yes! Even if they  gow another direction, I'm sending them a thank you. 
 
2. Volunteer To Do The Dirty Work: Every tour or program has a role that nobody wants  or is the least popular. Don't just do it, be the best damn "whatever" you can possibly be doing it. Don't over dramatize your contribution.  Any good manager already knows that this task is the least popular and appreciates your "sacrifice". As a manager, I support favoritism. When someone makes my life easier by volunteering for a less glorious role it often comes with perks. Longer or more frequent breaks, excess swag, opportunity to earn extra hours when it allows. Whatever I can do for that person, I do without hesitation. Think that person gets an exceptional feedback report from me? Hell yeah! They're also usually the person I ask for when I return to that market for future opportunities.

3. Be The First & The Last: It's very rare that anyone beats me to an event. Sometimes I'm even there before a manager in my brand experience support roles. I also try to be the last one to leave. Obviously a challenge for those who are stacking multiple opportunities in a single day but try. I want to be the first and last face my manager and colleagues see. You'd be surprised by some of the opportunities that come about as a result of being there before the rest of the gang arrives and after they leave.
 
4. Pack A Spare: Working long hours at a trade show or event? Get a lunch break? Pack a spare sandwich. Odds are someone forgot or didn't have time to pack a lunch. Or maybe it's a newbie that didn't realize how ridiculous venue menu prices are. It instantly turns a stranger into your biggest cheerleader. Pack a box cutter. As minor as it sounds, being able to offer a knife to cut a box, zip tie, etc is appreciated. Bring a phone charger. I've charged attendees, colleagues, and manager's phones.  Nothing says "I'm not like the others" like being prepared by packing a spare.
 
5. Set Goals:  Not setting some measurable and realistic goals is like asking yourself to hit a bulls-eye wearing a blindfold. Pursuing and hitting those goals, whatever they may be, not only drives you when the going gets tough, but I guarantee your competition isn't doing it. I know plenty of wishers but very few goal setters. The goal setters in my life look much happier than the wishers....just sayin'.
 
6. Birds & Water: We've all heard the adages. Birds of a feather & water seeking its own level. If your professional circle doesn't share in the same want to be, have, and do more in this industry by setting yourself apart from the competition then guess what? It's time to find a new circle. Don't worry though. They'll be available to hang out with at the club or bar after you're done with your event. That's when you can listen to them whine about how few gigs there are or how poor the pay is. Just make sure you bring some extra cash because they "forgot" to bring any.
 
7. Call Me Crazy: Anybody that has ever set themselves from the pack and accomplished anything significant was originally thought to be crazy. You have an industry related idea. Notice there wasn't a question mark at the end of the previous sentence. Maybe you haven't worked out all the details. Maybe you're worried that it might not be well received. Whatever your idea is, I encourage you to start putting in motion. Own it and make that idea synonymous with your name. Just get used to being called crazy.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Josh! Good to hear from you Brother. I consider it a privilege to serve our community.

item.title: It's been three months and still no check. What to do.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
The social media universe has been clamoring for The Good Guys to address this unfortunate yet seemingly common scenario. Now that promo season is upon us we are seeing these grievances more and more on just about every social media platform we participate in. What we talk about in this post is something that has happened to us and many of our colleagues. Although we have many views on the subject one thing that we can all frankly agree upon is that it sucks. Let's tackle it together, intelligently, honestly and as professionals.

We all know the story. You've done everything required. Agreed to the rate. Submitted all your paperwork. Showed up early ready to rock. Killed the event. Turned in your hours on time for payment. 30 days go by...no check. 60 days...no check. 90 days and still no check. If you're like most in the industry, you're living check to check. Hey....I said it, but it's the truth. Some of it is by our own  lack of financial responsibility and some of it is the nature of the beast. I've been guilty myself. Your bills are due every 30 days yet you have checks landing all over the calendar. Most likely not when your bills are due like folks who have a 9-5 job. This can definitely add stress to your situation. Like Big Worm from Friday said "Playin' with my money is like playin' with my emotions."

     When it comes to not getting paid in a reasonable amount of time I'm a firm believer in the "burnt once shame on you burnt twice shame on me" rule. Plain and simple. If you've had a bad experience getting timely payment from a company why would you ever work for them again? Do you like wasting your time arm wrestling a company who holds the clear advantage in this scenario? I'd rather spend my time looking for other opportunities.

  Ask questions. When you're being booked and considered for an opportunity it's perfectly acceptable to ask the booking agent about the payment cycle or practices of their agency. If they tell you that they pay their independent contractors every 60 or 90 days don't expect to get a check any earlier than that. If done in a professional and conversational tone, it's not as big as a deal as one might think. I always ask. Even with companies I've done business with in the past because things change.

    If it's a new agency or a company I haven't heard of doing some research before signing anything is always beneficial. Reach out to colleagues or social media groups. The Internet is a tool that is greatly underutilized. Look at their website and don't hesitate to do a BBB inquiry. Agencies inquire about you and your business practices using social media and Internet references so don't be afraid to do the same. If they have nothing to hide they'll be proud of their accomplishments and reputation.

 Make copies of EVERYTHING! I can't stress this enough. Not saying that the "We don't have your paperwork" hasn't been used as a delay tactic but in reality it has happened with no ill intent. You're dealing with human beings and things happen. Even computers have been known to lose critical paperwork that is vital to getting paid. Being able to produce a copy of all your paperwork to be sent over immediately should get you in on the next pay cycle. If you've been a cool-headed professional, treated the person on the other end of the line respectfully, you might have made yourself a friend and an exception to their pay cycle.

 So you've done all the above, spoke to accounting, the booking agent and it's still getting you nowhere. Here is where you have to thoroughly evaluate your situation, and each one is different. Are you waiting for a check for a one day event, 3 hours at 15 bucks an hour? Or are you waiting for a 10 day event, 8 hours each day at 25 bucks an hour?  Whether it's an example I've just given or somewhere in between, you have to decide if expending the time and energy to get your check is worth it. If you've said yes then this is what to do...

 Email the owner of the agency. I'd say call but in reality we are more likely to open and read an email than answer a call. In your email detail your actions up to the date of the email. Hopefully, you've documented the emails and calls you've made thus far. In your documentation be as detailed as possible. Times, dates and people you've spoken to. What if any content of those conversations. You'll need this documentation if you decide to pursue legal action. Having documentation also lets the owner know that you have your "ish" in order, that you're a professional and that you're done playing around.

Still no luck?  The natural response is to go social media ex-boyfriend/girlfriend style on them right? Wrong. However self gratifying and deserved, bashing a company on social media has very rarely produced positive results in my experience. If it's on their site or page it's easily removed. It also subliminally makes you look bad to other agencies who hold keys to other opportunities. 99% of event marketing agencies are honest, respectable, and fair. Let's not lose sight of that because the 1% who are not. Use social media only to reach out to those who may be experiencing the same problem with the same company for a potential class action suit. A simple "Has anyone been paid for xyz promotion for xyz company yet?"  without getting overly negative should suffice. Reaching out to those individuals over a group chat will keep you from being MIS-labeled a whistle blower or whiner.

 "To call the client or not call the client? That is the question." I have mixed feelings about this. This is where many of us depart on philosophies. Reason being is sometimes the cause for you not receiving your check is because the client has not paid the agency. At any rate, if you chose this course of action consider the bridge burned. Remember, keep your cool. I never recommend side stepping the agency to attain work. However if the client decides not to do business with the agency because of it's poor business practices it opens the door to being hired by the client directly. This should NEVER be used as a tool to circumvent honest and fair agencies that have held up their end of the agreement.

 "It's time to get the band together." It's come to this. You've decided that it's time for some action, some class action. Odds are you're not the only person that this company has burnt. Companies, like humans, are creatures of habit. If they've burned you, odds are they've burned others too. Filing a claim with your local, and if possible their local government district attorney's office has yielded results in the past. You will also have provided a reference for others who have taken the time to do their research on the company, potential future clients included.

goodguysdofinishfirst.wordpress.com

item.title: Full Commitment for a Part Time Opportunity
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
After hours and hours of scouring the internet for opportunities, a program has caught your attention. The compensation fits within your requirements. You have the experience and a connection with the brand.  With your qualifications and outgoing personality, you've made a great impression on the initial screening call. You've prepared and rehearsed for the next interview because you're on the short list of candidates to speak with your potential new boss or client. Everything is starting to shape up. You know that this opportunity was meant for you. Then the bomb drops. The program is executed over several months.  The activations and your compensation are a few days out of each of those months. The client or agency has expressed selecting their candidates based on being able to commit to the entire program. Uhhhh yeah. Tough one.  The Good Guys love discussing challenging topics. Our living room is literally an open forum for which industry trends and practices are frequently discussed.  As we evaluate opportunities to exceed everyone's expectations this scenario and discussion come up quite frequently. Hopefully, we can provide some insight on how to approach this challenge as a true professional.
The client or agency's thoughts: We're offering a great opportunity to this candidate from a highly competitive talent pool. If he or she won't commit to the entire program, we'll find someone who will. We want consistency and continuity throughout the program. We don't have time to reinvest in the interview and training process again. Our budget only allows for one candidate to be brought into the program. Every company has a bottom line. They have to fly you in, cover your meals, and eventually return you to your home market. These things affect the profitability of every program. Candidate's thoughts: It's impossible to predict what the future holds. What if I'm offered a more consistent position with significant  financial rewards and personal gratification? It's a great opportunity, but it's temporary and part-time. How can i commit fully when the agency or client is investing in my services partially?
"Good" thoughts: Both sides have valid concerns. We believe that  we all work hard to create a better tomorrow. Each party has the same goal. How they perceive to accomplish that goal is obviously very different. The agency or client has expended a large amount of time and financial resources. Their reputation and branding are at stake with every project they undertake. The candidate in most cases, has only one employee, themselves. They are their one and only resource to generate income. Candidates in the event marketing industry are brought in, as independent contractors, with no guarantee of future employment even under exemplary project performance. So what should you do under this circumstance as a candidate? The Good Guys know that this is a difficult but, unfortunately, common scenario. A scenario both of us have encountered in our endeavors. Addressing it as a professional might not necessarily land you the opportunity today but the future is a big place. 1. Honesty is the best policy. If you're a strong candidate for a future program or have obligations down the road, let it be known. If you plan on making a career in this industry your credibility and integrity is the currency that buys longevity and stability. Even though there are a countless number of agencies, word travels fast and key players change employers. Perspective companies will respect your honesty, leaving the door open for potential future consideration. Or at the very least, not blacklist you. You'll also sleep better at night knowing that bad mojo hasn't painted a bullseye on your backside. 2. Open the dialog. People in the event marketing industry are some of the best problem solvers on the face of the planet.  You should never lose sight that you belong to a family of people who face some of the strangest and challenging obstacles and still find a way to overcome them. By opening up dialog that incorporates solutions, not only do you keep yourself in the running but it also demonstrates your problem-solving skills. 3. Put the decision maker or interviewer in your shoes. Although people in our industry are great problem solvers, we are also very goal oriented. If finding a qualified candidate that can make the full commitment is their goal, most likely they won't see the situation as you do. Recently I was put in this exact scenario with the same proposition of total commitment. When I shared with my interviewer my concerns  of such a commitment in an intelligent, non-confrontational, real-world tone, I could almost hear the light bulb in their head switch on. The person on the other end of the line is a human being with hopes, fears, and challenges, just like you and I. Talk to them about your concern as one human being to another and you might be surprised by the results. 4. Put yourself in their shoes. The agency has entered a legally binding agreement to produce a product. They've wooed and wowed the client with the promise of a first class program.  I've never known an agency to promise anything less than the best. The agency's only chance of survival hinges on the ability to furnish the best program possible with the least amount of client exposed adversity. This scenario doesn't have to be a risk if there is trust and a clear plan in place. However, some agencies operate on minimal margins or have limited resources to institute a contingency plan. So don't take it personally if they choose a less qualified candidate that offers a level of perceived security. Remember, this is a business. If an arrangement is not mutually beneficial then either side is entitled to walk away from it. If you've been honest, created a great reputation based on networking and a solid work ethic, there will be other opportunities.

item.title: Tour Manager Checklist: Preparing For Events
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Being a tour manager in event marketing is one of the most rewarding opportunities within our industry. It also carries the most responsibility. Your problem solving skills are put to the test on almost a daily basis. Throw in the constantly changing needs of the client with an already tight schedule, and a simple oversight of locking the only set of keys to the event vehicle inside of it could lead to you ceremoniously counting down the days until the tour is over.
Any seasoned tour manager will tell you that things are going to happen, but being prepared separates the good managers from the greats. In this article I’ve outlined a few helpful tips that will not only keep you organized, but also, more importantly, keep you sane. In the perfect world, you’d like to have this checklist finished 24 hours before the event, but as we know, the event world is often far from perfect.  Do your best to have everything done the night before, and you’ll be in better shape than those who save it for the morning.
1.     Charge Your Stuff- Make sure that not only the event technology and event camera is charged but also your own cell phone. Having an extra battery or a Juice Pack is also a good idea since not every venue will have outlets.
2.     Fuel Up- Gas up the event vehicles and generators. With a corporate card and plenty of stations there should be no reason to make something simple as a fuel a hurdle.
3.     Wash Your Vehicle- Brands are utilizing more eye catching vehicles with elaborate graphic designs to increase brand awareness. Rolling into an event with a less than clean vehicle diminishes that return on investment and reflects poorly on you immediately. Keep a bottle of glass cleaner, Tire Wet, spray wax and a soft cloth to touch up between washes and especially before activation.
4.     Look Sharp- Wearing a clean, pressed and stain free uniform says a lot about you. It establishes credibility not only with attendees, but also with your event contact and locally hired staff. Bring a spare uniform in case gremlins spill your Red Bull on your shirt.
5.     Check the Weather- Regardless if the event is inside or out, there is no reason to be surprised by the weather.  Could the weather delay your arrival to the venue? Do you need to bring any weather appropriate garments for yourself and the staff? It also can be an indicator of what kind of day lays ahead. Also not bad to know for reporting later.
6.     Map Your Route- Critical when you are unable to perform a site check. Consider what traffic may be like the day and times of your commute.  Being late is not an option as a tour manager, so leaving yourself plenty of time to get to the venue is critical.
7.     Call Your Staff- Assuming that the staffing agency or your account manager has forwarded staff contact information, a brief call the day before the event can alleviate many potential headaches.  No shows, late arrivals, and the “where are you” calls five minutes before strike went down significantly after making staff calls a part of my regiment as a tour manager.
8.        Get Some Sleep- Being on the road is an exciting experience. You get to meet new people and go places you’ve never been. Having said that, don’t forget why you are where you are. Both professionally and geographically. A company and their brand are expecting you to give 110% to their cause. Partaking in the local nightlife or going to bed late can make a potentially challenging day a nightmare.  Not to mention the fact that schedules and tasks are often changing, so an “easy” day on the schedule doesn’t necessarily mean you can go “hard” the night before.
  I hope that this checklist will serve as a useful guide to the new tour managers out there and a friendly reminder to the veterans of the industry.  Keep an eye out within this forum for other best practices of successful tour managers.
goodguysdofinishfirst.wordpress.com

item.title: Brand Ambassador 101 contributed by Tieira Ryder
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
I met Tieira Ryder managing a program on behalf of Lowes Home Improvement at CES over two years ago. She immediately set herself apart from her 12 other co-workers with her great personality, professionalism and genuine smile. In her article, she succinctly breaks down the definition and role of a brand ambassador. Tieira shares the secret of her success and what it takes to make sure that she is the first person to be called for staffing opportunities. Click the link below to see her full contribution.

Brand Ambassador 101 by Tieira Ryder

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank you Tieira for allowing us to share your insight. And congrats on being our first comment. You always remember your first...lol.

item.title: How to have an outstanding 2015. Lessons learned from watching "Walking Dead."
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Originally this month's blog was going to be focused on goals. I planned on illustrating the dynamics of goal setting, how to effectively execute a goal setting program and the power the most successful people in the world enjoy as a result of their dedication and accountability. How by declaring your aspirations in great detail and taking persistent action toward that destination, 2015 could be the best year ever. I was prepared to deliver that message with full conviction. It then became clear to me that you, our reader, didn't need a reminder of the year's end. You didn't need a reminder that around the exact same time last year, you had hopes of what 2014 would bring. Well? Was it everything you had hoped it would be?

I felt uninspired and disappointed. I had nothing of value to share with you that you haven't already heard. No "go get 'em tiger" words or insightful observations that would send you into 2015 energized and refocused for the opportunities and challenges ahead. I resigned to rethink how I could best make use of your valuable time. Without any  clear direction, I decided to take a break and turn on the television. The following post is the result of what happened next. "Walking Dead." Their apocalypse. Your guide to an awesome 2015. For those who are not familiar with the show, the premise seems rather simple, the living vs the dead. Watch it once and you'll immediately know that this ain't yo momma's zombie apocalypse horror flick.The writers have gone to great lengths in providing each character with a deep and complex profile. The actors do a great job of making themselves relatable to the audience, even in their darkest hours. Throw all the characters together, toss in a few zombies, a dash of scarce resources and you've got yourself a hit tv show. Getting lost in the characters and their struggle to survive comes easy. We all know a Eugene or at the very least a Maggie in our lives. Getting caught up in"if that were me" or "I bet you that this happens next" conversations are so popular that AMC added a show that dives deeper into "Walking Dead's" twists and turns like a therapy session. The show clearly stirs the argument of life imitating art or art imitating life conversations. As professionals in the event marketing industry, just like the characters in the show, we have a goal. The goal to "survive" may have different meanings to each of you.To you "surviving" may be taking on more responsibility in an elevated role. To somebody else it may be the introduction of a new service or learning how to effectively manage your time. Another person's survival may be tied to new business development. Then there are some of us who woke up today and realized that life, as they had known it, was no longer going to be the same. I call them episode one people....lol...poor things. With all the great details and added layers to the show created by the talented writers, one thing struck a chord with me. A lesson that resonated so clearly that I felt I had to share. I almost missed it, and it was in front of me all the time. Any guesses? THE ZOMBIES! The zombies are the straw that stirs the apocalyptic drink. They are the single most dangerous element in the entire tale. Their presence on the show is nearly ambient until one of the living gets cornered or falls within biting range of them. Well then there is also the surprise attack from within the wall of an unexpected victim. Other than those cameo appearances, they almost blend in with the background with moans and synchronized swaying of limbs. What draws me into this train of thought is this. Despite having to search for food, water and a safe place to rest, the living will go to the farthest reaches of morality, to avoid becoming a zombie. They are faced with having to lie, cheat, steal and sometimes even kill the ones they love to avoid a zombie's life....or death....or is it life? Whichever the case may be, one could defend the existence of being a zombie is not all that bad. You'd never die, unless you're beheaded or pierced with a bullet. You're sole existence and only care is to eat human flesh. No need to sleep, drive cars, or go to work. Everyone seemingly gets along well and despite moving at a ridiculously slow speed, their teamwork compensates for that shortcoming. Even with all this harmony and easy living, our survivors fight on but why?

I suppose that when faced with an existence that lacks the experiences that shape us into who we are, just getting by is a fate worse than death. The characters on "Walking Dead" would rather face adversity, evaluate choices, take measured risks, learn new skills, suffer great losses, make mistakes while discovering unknown strength and determination to achieve the goal of remaining alive. Not only to just exist but to remain uniquely themselves. That speaks volumes to the value of choosing our own path. Choice is an ability that all men and women have to play a decisive role in creating our own futures. You don't have to look far to find people who understand what a great opportunity each day brings. You are not subject to the wind and where it takes you. I challenge each of our readers to avoid what Henry David Thoreau called "a life of quiet desperation." Let's choose not to be zombies in 2015.

item.title: Poor staff pay rates. Who's to blame and why.
item.dc:creator: GoodGuyRobertAdams
item.content:encoded:
Ripped straight from your favorite social media sites over a 4  hour period.

One didn't have to go far to hear about all of the injustices that agencies were shackling this year's CES staff with.

But no topic was hotter than pay rates. By the sounds of things, you'd swear the North Hall was being renovated into a third world sweatshop.

Yet talent still came in from far and wide to be a part of CES.

So why all of the public moaning?

Do these grievances have any merit?

And if so why?

  [caption id="attachment_1600" align="aligncenter" width="362"] Whining about rate only makes you look unprofessional.[/caption]

Let me first start off by saying this, bashing a company over something impersonal as rate serves nobody.

In fact, it's a disservice to yourself. Check-mark blacklisted.

No agency or account manager will care how right you were and your colleagues will not send you a check for your "standing up to the establishment" nobility.

Yes, your intentions are good but all that they will remember is that you bashed another company.

Publicly.

No Bueno.

  I don't tolerate rate bashing on of my sites and cringe when I see people do it on sights that I visit.

 Now in the comfort of my home, I've shared many undocumented and sometimes curse-laden conversations regarding rate. None that you could go back to and make part of your blog, but I've had them still the same.

 Notice earlier how I said that rate was "impersonal." Often times we confuse a posting's rate as how a company or group values us personally. Nothing could be further from the truth. Professionals in every career path face these same challenges. For the sake of this post, I draw the comparison to being a pro athlete. Except ESPN isn't there to cover it and we're not talking about millions of dollars. But the principals are still the same. The last words you hear, he or she say is..."it was nothing personal...this is a business and this event was a business decision".

       Everyone deserves to be paid what they are worth.

However, there are times when opportunity, skills, and the means to properly compensate for a set of skills don't come together.

There's a ton of things I'd have if money were no object.

Unfortunately, money is an object in our world and in the world of corporate budgets. I don't profess to know other people's finances nor do I incorporate it in determining my acceptable rate.

Which goes to my next point.

         Determining what is fair.

 Las Vegas has a ridiculous amount of talent. Performers, hard-bodies, multilingual and everything else in between.

Even more so when CES comes to town.

The market becomes saturated with amazing people with unbelievable skill sets.

           

 Supply and demand.

People had come from as far east as New York and as far north as Washington State.

There were professionals here that came without having CES booked. Were there opportunities for them? Absolutely!

Did everyone who came out get hired? No.

Notice the price of gasoline lately?

Based on the price of a gallon of gas alone, anybody can guess that there must be plenty of petroleum available right? I wanted to ask one of these disgruntled colleagues if they don't mind still paying 3.50 a gallon since that's what the cost of gas was last year? But by far my favorite disgruntled poster had this to say.....

"WOW! not even $100/day which I thought was the lowest rate I saw. You would think the CEO of a company would be able to afford more than $10/hour! "

           I get it.

Ten bucks is a rate that I wouldn't consider any time of year, especially during CES. But let's not rush to conclusions. CEO stands for Chief Executive Officer. Not Cash Everywhere O'lawd. It's a title that signifies a person's position within a company. It comes with no endowment or near death rich uncles or distant relatives. Not every person, that adorns that title, is in a position to pay whatever average pay rate was during last week. Should that person not have posted the 10.00 per hour job at all even though they were in need of staff?

Most CEOs, that I would consider successful in this industry, have experienced some tough challenges to get where they are today.

Cash flow and money management issues being a constant challenge, businesses must constantly be sensitive to overhead and labor costs just to stay afloat. I had a CEO once tell me that he had to take out a loan to make payroll. Not by his own poor decision-making skills but as a result of a slow paying client and the growth of his agency. While being an entrepreneur brings another level of pride, staying afloat is not the reason why people go into business. Think managing your own career and finances are tough? Try running a business of any scale. Better yet, try starting one.

 Now by no means am I letting agency policymakers off the hook.

Nor am I committed to driving my disgruntled colleagues out to the desert never to be seen from again. What I do ask is that before making a negative statement that reflects poorly on yourself and your colleagues with no result, put yourself in the other person's shoes. Everything isn't always what it seems and business decisions are very rarely personal. These are principles that affect both sides of the partnership between staff and the agencies that hire us. If the rate doesn't meet your requirements, not applying for the position is the loudest message any of us could ever send.

item.title: Resource Review..."The Brand Ambassadors Handbook" -by Edwin J. Goitia
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
I was  surprised when friend and colleague Edwin J. Goitia, from PromoRockstar, asked me to review his new book. For one, I know a published author. And two, an author wanted my honest evaluation of his work. Challenge accepted.

A "Must Have" Book. Long overdue.

It would've been easy to give this book a glowing review, solely based on the many in-depth and productive conversations Edwin and I have had. His extensive knowledge of every facet of marketing and live event mechanics was never in question. The challenge I looked forward to evaluating was his ability to provide a useful tool for newbies without abandoning his core supporters. After purchasing "The Brand Ambassadors Handbook" on Amazon.com, for less than a dollar, I dove right in.

 With the word "handbook" in the title, the beginning obviously dedicates itself to explaining what it "is" that we exactly do. Not only in a physical sense, but also the psychology of event marketing. Edwin carefully balances between simplification and providing information of value. The table setting introduction was refreshing. I was reminded of views and interactions that vets like myself take for granted.

[caption id="attachment_812" align="alignleft" width="252"] Edwin J. Goitia[/caption]

Throughout the book, Edwin shares how his personal life and his career path have impacted each other. No sugar-coating in pointing out the rewards and potential pitfalls of our line of work and  life.

My favorite part of his book are the "Golden Rules" and "Ethics" section. I like this section the most because it serves as a definitive guideline for rookies but also as a compass for the not so new.

Anyone who works in the industry will find something of value in the pages. What gives the book value is not just the credibility of the author and his experience, but also its honest approach without being jaded. Informative without being a rah rah, you can do it book. My coworkers and I will greatly benefit from the key learnings that speak to professionals of different skill levels. The industry was well overdue for this book.  A must have for the career minded brand ambassador.

item.title: You're Fired! What's Next?
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
As a result of chance, circumstance, or of your own missteps, management has made the decision.

You're FIRED!

Feel like a bum. The timing of it couldn't have been any worse. Maybe you just made a major purchase like a car or house. Perhaps a loved one has recently passed away or the IRS finally caught up with you. Getting fired very rarely comes at the right time. If you've been with me since my goal setting post, I'm pretty sure getting fired wasn't on that list.. So what's next? My answers and the answers of some of the most sought after talent might surprise you. Come have a seat my friend. Your desire to learn has brought you here. Together, we'll get through this. I got ya. First thing I want you to do is breathe. Our creator gave us some great tools to withstand physically demanding challenges. Being hunted down by prey bigger and stronger  than ourselves. Extended periods without nourishment or shelter. Time and time again, humans have proven to be resilient, even under dire predicaments. Rest assured during that breathe. No bears. No wolves. And you're reading this from your computer or smart phone. 911 assistance doesn't require references or proof of income so we're already ahead of our ancestors. "Failure is an event. Not a person."  - Zig Ziglar [caption id="attachment_994" align="aligncenter" width="400"] Failure is apparently a suit too...[/caption] One and only "Zen Master" quote. Promise. The men and women of this industry are a progressive community. We make our clients happy by collectively merging ideas, function and execution. It's the very nature of what we do. Once you've performed that task a few hundred times a year, your pride wants more. Your favorite hats no longer fit quite the same. Now you've got a set of war stories and accomplishments that'd make your grandfather proud. But beware, the pendulum swings both ways. The same brain and swag that solidified your abilities and position among your superiors and earned the adulation and sometimes jealousy of colleagues has a bigger challenge ahead. Did you see it coming? Most cases, not likely. You've just been fired. You now belong to a group larger and more  accomplished than one might think.Despite the self-doubt, replays of the event and the ensuing uncertainty of your future, you're not the first to get fired. And hopefully not the last. Before becoming a world-famous boxing champion, George Foreman was fired from his job moving furniture. Stan Lee, the creator of Spider-Man was also fired. Mark Cuban, Walt Disney, Oprah, Robert Redford, Bill Belichick, and J.K. Rowling and yours truly. A Good Guy. Not quit. Fired. For many on this list, an eventual turn of fortune came many years after being fired. Everyone I know has been fired at one time or another. One off event or ten-month tour. Tour manager or account manager. They've all been fired. I stand fast to the philosophy that if you haven't been fired from a job, you have not found work that is worthy of your passion and focus. Of those who I polled, some went so far as to call someone who hasn't been fired a 'pushover". If you're new to the industry or to your position, I'm not encouraging you to get fired. If you truly enjoy what you do for a living, become a market "go to" guy or chica, do a few tours, and take pride in your craft, learn and conduct yourself with the same consistency that got you here. If it happens it happens. For some, once is enough. For others, a refresher on the subject may be in order. In an aggressive on to the next one environment, we'll discover how professionals navigate and in some cases excel their career path after being fired. In a word of mouth industry, getting fired sucks. (Queue the BIG E please......) Next week, you and I get honest.
"Turning negative to positive and it's all......." (Head nod)  I cringe at the thought of a world where a George Foreman grill doesn't exist. No Foreman?! Forget about it!
,

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In an industry that is about buzz and branding, the Good Guys share how to recover from being fired in the event marketing industry and what to do next.

item.title: You’re Fired! What’s Next? Navigating the Fallout.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
In an industry that focuses on branding, your name is your meal ticket. As a result of being fired, yours has just taken a hit. What are you going to do now?

[su_spacer]

If working in event marketing is more than just a gig, career decisions shouldn't be handled like ordering from the value menu at a fast food restaurant. So before making any rash decisions out of fear, spite or any other emotion, let's not lose the opportunity to learn the valuable lessons getting fired can provide. [caption id="attachment_519" align="alignleft" width="138"] Learn from your mistakes.[/caption] Learn from your mistakes. This sounds easy but in reality this is the toughest part of the process. Why? Because in order to learn from your mistakes, you must be completely honest with yourself.  To the point where you must be mentally comfortable accepting the possibility that you may have had a hand in your own firing. Either partially or fully. Even in bullshitting others about the details, you open your mind to the risk of making those lies a truth that you now believe yourself. Stick to the facts. Often times we allow emotions to disguise the truth. Yeah, so Joe or Josephine didn't like you. But what happened that gave Joe or Josephine the ammo they needed to fire you? [su_list icon="icon: arrow-circle-o-down"]
  • Were you consistently late?
  • Did you underperform?
  • Did your coworkers understand your role & responsibilities?
  • Did you understand theirs?
  • Was there a communication issue?
[/su_list] In today's workplace, it's acceptable that you don't have to like your co-workers or even your superiors in order to have a healthy and productive work relationship. It'd be nice, but it's not a necessity. Needless to say it requires another level of professionalism but it can and has been done. [caption id="attachment_1285" align="alignright" width="272"] Rumors[/caption] Go def. We work in a word of mouth industry. That's a fact. People are going to post, tweet, text, and talk. That's another fact. Some of the banter may be the truth. Some of it half truths. And some of it just flat out lies. Regardless, this banter serves nobody. If people have enough time to talk about your situation, it's because they have nothing positive going on in their lives. Successful people with goals and aspirations have no time to talk about another's shortcomings and failures. And that my friend is the biggest fact of all. Rest assured as soon as you are no longer front page worthy they'll move on to the next subject in their miserable existence. Every minute you spend in shame and obsessed with spin control is one minute longer you keep yourself from authoring your very own comeback story.
 [su_pullquote]"..stepping back gave me clarity..."[/su_pullquote]
Step Back & Move On..To some level, we are emotionally invested in the roles, programs and brands we represent. By stepping back, you open the door to possibilities that you may never have considered before. You might discover a new role or maybe even go back to an old role with a better understanding. Whatever the case may be, none of this magic can take place until you move on. [su_youtube url="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JREouTHpyJE" autoplay="no"] Dare I say......the great thing about getting fired is that not only do you find out who you are but you also find out who your friends are. Every once in a while we need to evaluate who we are. We also need an opportunity to evaluate the people who we choose to have in our lives. Nothing like the adversity of getting fired as the test. Who you are and who you chose to have in your circle has a profound effect in how quickly you get back up. [caption id="attachment_109" align="alignright" width="336"] Good Guys & Friends[/caption]

Like most people, the true number of friends is nowhere near what FaceBook says I have. But when the chips are down, you only need one true friend to help dust you off. Whether it's a word of encouragement, a few bucks to get you through the rough spots or just a reminder that no matter what happens, you're still one of the "Good Guys". And just like in the movies, the "Good Guys Always Win".

item.title: No Season For Bashing
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
It often amuses me how certain subjects and practices occur the same time of year just like clockwork. The subject of unions in the fall, late paychecks during winter, mobile tours in the spring, followed by music festival opportunities and dress codes in late spring to early summer. One widespread industry practice seems to never have a season as it happens all year long. [su_highlight background="#fd361e" color="#dee6cd"]BASHING[/su_highlight] Independent contractors bashing agencies. Agencies and booking agents bashing independent contractors. It's an endless and troubling cycle. When it happens, especially on social media, I don't know who I'm more disappointed with as a community. The "haves', agencies and talent coordinators. Or the 'have-nots", independent contractors, promotional models and brand ambassadors. It's undoubtedly clear that agencies are the "haves". They generally set policy and protocol on a majority of practices across the industry. They do all the hiring and cut almost all of the checks. The fact that they are in the clear position of power very rarely irks me. I view the relationship between agencies and myself as a mutualistic arrangement. One hand washes the other. Only the other hand gets a little more soap and water. Long as I'm clean, I'm good. What I call into question, is an heir of superiority that borders arrogance and hypocrisy. I was always taught that "the greatest of you are servants of all." "To whom much is given, much is expected." In this regard, the position of power agencies "have" as influencers of the industry, I hold them to a much higher standard. From someone who is not perfect but believes in the general goodness of people, the tones and ridicule of the uneducated or untrained from the ivory tower is disheartening. I challenge agencies and talent coordinators to spend half the energy they spend posting how this brand ambassador did this or didn't do this to change their focus. Perhaps by praising someone who is exceptional. Or dare I say even by mentoring someone who lacks the general understanding of our industry. Taking them under our wing. [caption id="attachment_1330" align="aligncenter" width="362"] Mentoring instead of mocking.[/caption] There are agencies and talent coordinators who understand their responsibility as leaders. Some go as far as offering training portals and "how-to" dialogs. To these agencies and talent coordinators, I applaud and respect you. Keep up the great work. To my fellow brothers and sisters in the field and behind the scenes, we are not off the hook either. Although we are the "have-nots" in this plea for professional decorum, we are not powerless. And yes, we've more than had a hand in perpetuating this ugly practice. [caption id="attachment_1331" align="alignleft" width="294"] Powerless[/caption]

I am guilty as well. That ends today.

Will I discontinue calling out things that I feel need to be changed?

No.

What I will do, in addition to calling out things that I feel need to be changed, is offer my resources or knowledge in contributing to that change that reflects positively on myself and my fellow brothers and sisters in the field.

Anytime that I do not do so, you have full permission to hold me accountable in any forum, public or private, for not doing so. The lesson learned from recent events in Baltimore, we can set fire and loot our community, stay locked in our houses and do nothing, or represent the best our community has to offer. Let's get out and clean up. [caption id="attachment_1334" align="aligncenter" width="258"] Together[/caption]

We can either choose to be part of the solution or part of the problem.

Agency or Brand Ambassador. We need to realize that we are all in this together.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Bashing in the event marketing industry is running rampant on social media. We call to action for a more professional decorum and mutual respect for all

item.title: 7 Reasons Why You're Not Getting Booked.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
For some of us, it's time to make hay.

Opportunities to get booked for an event or program are everywhere.

But for the top-notch professionals in our industry, the hustle knows no start or end.

They stay booked.

Some even pass over opportunities because they simply can't be two places at once.

Checks for events they forgot they had worked, seemingly fall from the sky.

Have the same problem? [su_animate type="slideInRight" delay="1.5"]No?[/su_animate]

 7 Reasons Why You're Not Getting Booked

1. Outdated profiles or resumes.

I'd love, LOVE a unified database that agencies could access to send out notifications. I know it's difficult to keep up with all the exclusive job portals, but you have to make an effort. At the very least, keep yourself updated with the agencies that seem to provide the most opportunities. Resumes should be updated to account for your recent projects. Let the old ones roll off your resume. But keep a copy in case a past project is uniquely relative to the position you're applying for. We live in a what have you done lately industry. Your resume should reflect that.   [caption id="attachment_1370" align="aligncenter" width="400"] Update Your Resume[/caption]

2. No network.

My definition of a network is a mutually beneficial relationship with like-minded people. Not a popularity contest. Not, "I'll talk, text or FaceBook ya only if I want something from you" relationship An arrangement where both sides share opportunities relative to each others skill sets. If you'd like to learn more about effective networking, check out "Networking vs. A Working Net."

3. Not "hawking" the lists.

Craigslist. FaceBook. Twitter. LinkedIn. No matter what your choice of social media may be, you must constantly keep your pipeline of opportunities filled.

[caption id="attachment_1367" align="aligncenter" width="400"] Be Constantly Looking[/caption]

A great way to accomplish that is by being constantly "hawking" these outlets for job posts. You should also be capable of applying for opportunities directly from your smartphone. Often times it's not always the most qualified that get hired, but the individual who applies the fastest.

4. Burned bridges.

Too many no calls / no shows? Bashed an agency or influential player in the industry over social media? Yeah...not a great idea.

5. No professional development.

Learn a new skill and stay up on industry trends. Your pretty face will only get you so far.

[caption id="attachment_1371" align="aligncenter" width="376"] Possibilities Are Endless. Invest In Yourself.[/caption] If event marketing is more than just a gig to you, there's no excuse why you can't dedicate an hour a week to better yourself. There are countless ways and outlets to further your skill set and understanding of the event marketing industry. I heard there's a pretty decent blog by some "Good Guys" that provides exactly that....lol. But seriously, you'd never go to a doctor, mechanic or lawyer that didn't stay up on best industry practices or learn a new skill. So why should an agency or brand expect anything less from you?]

6. No goals.

Before GPS, we used this thing called a map.  It was a tool us older folks used to navigate our destinations. If I wanted to drive to Miami from Atlanta, I'd pre-plan my route. Note obstacles and detours. Regardless of construction, traffic, or stops, as long as I checked the map every once in a while, I know I'd eventually reach my destination. [caption id="attachment_1369" align="alignleft" width="286"] To arrive at a destination, you gotta know where you are now and where you want to go.[/caption]

Your career destination should be no different. Don't just put the key in and drive with the hopes of reaching your professional destination.

Have goals.

7. No love.

If there is only one take-away from this post, I sincerely hope that what I'm about to say is IT.

If you count the minutes before you have to leave for your opportunity, hunched over, with repetitive sighs and devoid of any enthusiasm. Find another job.

[caption id="attachment_1368" align="alignnone" width="400"] Find What You Love & Be Happy[/caption]

I understand that there are days and projects that are harder than others. I've had them as well. I'm not asking for you to overdose on happy pills.

But honestly, if you have more bad days than good days, find something else and be happy.

Life is too short for anything less.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Emails not flooded with job notifications? Phone not ringing? Voicemail empty? The Good Guys share 7 reasons why you're not getting booked.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I absolutely loved this post. It was such a good read and flowed with enlightenment, encouragement and expertise! Keep up the great work and inspiration provided for your readers!
Thank you. I'm glad you enjoyed it. My sincere hope is that others will benefit from my successes and failures. Good or bad, I appreciate you taking the time to comment. Welcome to The Good Guys.

item.title: EventStaffr App vs. National Event Staffing Premium.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
Every day there seems to be a new staffing agency popping up. Along with their arrival, there's also another portal that independent contractors have to meticulously and repetitiously fill out. If you've been in the event marketing industry for any length of time, you know exactly what I'm talking about. Perhaps to stand out from the rest of the pack, there are some agencies that are taking a different approach to the process. Could they potentially change how staff acquire opportunities? Could this revolutionize how agencies book staff? Today we take a look at two. National Event Staffing Premium vs. EventStaffr     National Event Staffing offers two services. A basic free service, although they don't recommend using it, and also a premium service that will run you about 120 bucks a year.     The following information was gathered directly from their page.     Here is everything you get with a Pro Staff Account:
  • Exclusive access to all jobs $35/hr or greater!
  • Drastically increase your chances of getting noticed by our clients and getting hired fast!
  • Your Application is displayed to our clients the very second you apply for jobs, no waiting to get hired!
  • You are able to add 5 additional photos to your profile page, our clients normally require this!
  • Your application is displayed at top of the list before any of our other staff who apply.
  • Your application is displayed in BOLD print allowing our clients to quickly see who has a Pro Account.
  • Your application is marked VIP so our clients know you mean business and are ready to work at their events!
  • You have 24-hour access to our Event Services Support Team who are here to make sure you get lots of great jobs!
  • Your paycheck is processed with VIP priority after each event to make sure you get paid fast!
  • Exclusive access to invite-only industry parties and events where you have a chance to network and socialize.
  • Special offers, promo items, and sample products that we only offer to our Pro Staff.
  • If you have Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, we can help get you more followers and more traffic to your pages.
  • Working with our amazing clients will give you great contacts to help further your career or educational goals.
  • Meet new friends and make lifelong connections as you work with our other fantastic staff at each event.
  • All this and more for only $119.40/year.
 SAY WHAT?!
 [su_spacer]
Here is a classic case of the road to hell being paved with good intentions.
  [su_spacer]
When I spoke to a representative from NES, the message they were focused on was making sure that staff took these opportunities seriously.
 [su_spacer]
That staff didn't flake, no-call / no-show, or perform poorly on-site.
 [su_spacer]
NES's philosophy is.. "If our staff invest financially in the process, the less likely these things will happen."
 [su_spacer]
Unfortunately, being an independent contractor myself, the only language that pops out at me is phrases like.." paycheck is processed with VIP priority after each event to make sure you get paid fast" and "Drastically increase your chances of getting noticed by our clients and getting hired fast!"
 [su_spacer]
It's like wait a minute, you mean to tell me that you want me to pay you so that you'll pay me quicker?
 [su_spacer]
And if a client notices me over a paid member will I not get the booking?
 [su_spacer]
Did I understand that correctly?
 [su_spacer]
If I pay for the service, will I undoubtedly get booked more often?
 [su_spacer]
The first part of their ideology I understand. All the other dialog surrounding it, I admittedly do not.
 [su_spacer]
Now the folks at Victory Marketing Agency have gone a different direction with an app called "EventStaffr".[su_spacer]
It was made very clear to me that this app is a separate entity from Victory. But with Victory's owner, Vinny Antonio and his chief marketing specialist, Casey Ayers driving the app into existence, the ties are easy to draw.
 [su_spacer]
During the research process, they were both very helpful and forthcoming by providing all the information I needed for this post.
[su_spacer]
I sent them a brief questionnaire.
[su_spacer]
This is what they sent back.
[su_spacer]
EventStaffr is a mobile app that allows field staff to find and book event work with the push of a button through their smartphones.
 [su_spacer]
  • Does it cost anything? Memberships, fees, etc?
Nope, nothing. We love our Staffrs and would never charge them anything to book events through our platform.
[su_spacer]
  • Any pre-qualifications or criteria as an IC to use the app?
Anyone can download and use the app. Applicants are screened and vetted via a phone interview before being booked for an event to ensure quality for customers.
[su_spacer]
  • Special features?
I wouldn't call any of the features "special". We're just building a better and faster way for people to find temporary event work in their hometown.
[su_spacer]
  • Why was the app developed?
For ICs, finding and applying for event gigs is a never-ending task. Staff have to login to different systems with different agencies, check calendars, check emails, follow-up on missed calls, payments, etc. It's very cumbersome and time consuming. We wanted to simplify the way staff found and booked gigs.
[su_spacer]
  • Future teaser features?
Our focus is less on features and more on building a great app that people will want to use. We're very proactive on receiving feedback and making updates quickly. We want ICs to love using our app.
[su_spacer]
Your Opinion Counts
Tell us what you think.
Have you used either one of these services?
If so, what were the pros and cons?
Would you pay for a service if you knew you'd get booked more often?

item.title: The Blacklist.
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded: It was only a couple of weeks ago perusing through my FaceBook feeds, I ran into a post that caught my attention. In short , the post described the individual's climb through the ranks, his own passion for the industry and the appreciation of everyone's role in the event marketing profession. Now an agency owner himself, he periodically shares insights that I find to be consistent, fundamentally sound while being forward-thinking. Anthony Russo, from Identity Marketing, is a big picture guy who is not afraid to make an impact on both sides of the experiential marketing fence. The highlight of his post was an industry wide call to action. Sharing many of my own "we're all in this together" sentiments from the Good Guy's "No Season For Bashing" post in April, Mr. Russo brought a discussion to the table that was long overdue. His plea called for a mutual appreciation and respect for each of our roles and responsibilities in a community of professionals. The end of cynicism with emphasis on the conduct, of both agencies and brand ambassadors, in the world of social media. [caption id="attachment_1662" align="alignright" width="334"] What's Fair?[/caption] What had caught me off guard about the post is that it was a re-post from almost a year ago. On another talent coordinator's page. Who worked for a different agency. As if that weren't  enough, the post was on a page that belongs to an individual who I find to be very vocal about their less than positive experiences with independent contractors. And who has no problem sharing those insights on social media outlets. She's a respected talent coordinator, who works for a reputable agency, and is quite active on social media. As a result, her posts create some lengthy and colorful threads. Having friends and strong business relationships, that work on the agency side, I have no doubt that what she shares is the truth.  And even though  I have mention her here, she is not alone in the practice. So what was up with this post? Did she have a change of heart? Maybe a Charles Dickens moment? [caption id="attachment_1660" align="alignright" width="348"] courtesy of homecinemachoice.com[/caption] No matter the reason, bashing each other over social media needs to stop.What I saw made me optimistic. But that moment would be short-lived. Two clicks of the mouse later, I'd land on another page. From the corner of my eye, a page suggestion caught my attention. The page name..."The Brand Ambassadors Blacklist". Dedicated to safeguarding agencies against bad brand ambassadors, had yet another FaceBook group. Really? [caption id="attachment_1651" align="alignright" width="283"] Blacklist Group Description[/caption] The Good Guys are dedicated to serving the community. If our experience, advice or resources lead to a better tomorrow for everyone, count us in. Even if it means challenging common practices and industry culture. The right thing is always the right thing. So before diving into the subject, let's define what "blacklisting" is at the core, according to Wikipedia. "A blacklist (or black list) is a list or register of entities or people who, for one reason or another, are being denied a particular privilege, service, mobility, access or recognition. As a verb, to blacklist can mean to deny someone work in a particular field, or to ostracize a person from a certain social circle." "... In the past, blacklists of union members have been shared or circulated between multiple organizations to prevent hiring of employees who, rather than being incompetent, have been critical of management actions. People have been prevented from working for decades due to being on a blacklist; in some cases the information on the blacklist was false." Hmmm. That doesn't sound good now does it? Another classic case of the road to hell being paved with good intentions. Not that I wasn't aware that these sort of groups existed, nor was I overly surprised by its members. What I couldn't get over was the tone and branding of the page. The first message I received  was "we exclude people." Being a minority, that message resonated again on another level. What was more intriguing is that I wasn't even looking for the page. It was a suggestion. So if I found it, who's to say that a perspective client won't find it. You know, the brands the page was meant to protect. In a field where image and brand messaging are the tools of our craft, this page deserved much more thought. Especially with a clear hardline stance and function. The page goes on to say that it serves as a notice to brand ambassadors. To demonstrate that a line of communication exists within the group's members. You mean to tell me that it didn't before? I find that hard to believe but okay. So why am I bringing this to everyone's attention? The answer is many fold. First and foremost is to educate everyone that they do exist. They are not rumor or speculation but very real. [caption id="attachment_1663" align="alignright" width="309"] Blacklists are very real.[/caption] Having seen how these lists function, it doesn't take much for one's name to be on it. Ever been late or called off for a legitimate reason? Even once? Your name could be on that list. Ever rub an account manager the wrong way or file a discrepancy in pay or schedule. Perhaps due to a breakdown in communication? Your name could be on that list. Now to their defense, do agencies have the right to hold independent contractors accountable? Absolutely! If you consistently no call / no-show or demonstrate a pattern of unprofessional behavior, you should be held accountable to your actions and deal with the repercussions. What I call in to question is the system of checks and balances for such a tool. Since the "list" is only accessible by agencies and their talent coordinators, there are no means to defend your reputation. [caption id="attachment_1661" align="alignright" width="214"] courtesy of demandprogress.org[/caption] No opportunity to respond to a grievance or supply any relevant information regarding any claim. This would, at very least, give the jury a chance to come to their own conclusion. In a landscape, where agencies and talent coordinators clearly have the power, the current structure of "blacklists" puts independent contractors in a role of dependency and not of partnership. With all the resources and tools that are available, can we come up with a system that is fair to everyone?

item.title: Time Stamped Photos. Is It Fair?
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
We've all been there. It's 7 am and you've just opened your eyeballs. After rolling to the other side of your bed, you wake up your money maker. Your cell phone or laptop. What happened on social media while you were asleep? After browsing the statuses of your friends and family, you decide it's a good ideal to check for job postings. As we all know in the independent contractor game, it's the early bird that gets the worm. A post for an opportunity catches your eye. Pay is right. You're available. And you match all the criteria. Time to shift gears and get into submission mode. You've got your standard-issue submission packet locked, loaded, and ready to go. You read the submission instructions further and wait! They want a time-stamped photo. "Like right now?" you ask yourself. If you want any shot of booking this opportunity, yeah, right now! Lucky for me, I keep a short/shaved hairstyle. [caption id="attachment_1702" align="alignleft" width="242"] Me at 7:30 AM.[/caption] Being male, I also don't have to go through the process of putting on any make-up. But even so, is this the image I want to portray of myself? Does how I look portray confidence and professionalism? More importantly, is the 7:30 AM image of me good enough to book this opportunity? Like it or not, it's gonna to have to be. Why? Because by the time I put my contacts in, shave, brush my teeth, and make myself presentable, the booking agent's inbox is already being flooded with applicants. [caption id="attachment_1717" align="alignright" width="199"] Professional By 8 AM.[/caption] And I'm a guy! I can't even imagine what this process must be like for my female colleagues. Nor do I pretend to. So the question begs to be asked. Why do agencies request time stamped photos for "today" and is this practice fair?

So why do agencies do it?

As a tour manager, agencies often forward me a quick profile of my staff. Names, emails, contact numbers and submission pics. The Good Guy's position, in the event marketing world, is to serve independent contractors but by no means anti-agency. So when I say agencies have us dead to rights when it comes to not providing "recent" pics, the grievance isn't even debatable. 7 out of 10 times, the person that shows up looks nothing like the photo I have of them. The pics are either heavily "touched-up" or outdated. And by outdated I mean I honestly wonder if the pic was taken within the last 2 years. Or even worse, if the pic was of a family member or distant cousin.

Is it fair?

This is where the debate begins. For those of who play by common sense rules, update any drastic changes, i.e. hair color/length change, tattoos, piercings, body type changes, etc, the answer is no. It's not fair. Time stamped? What am I? A deli sandwich? Bomb? Or some kind of fruit? Don't answer that last question... Unfortunately, as with anything, it only takes a few to ruin it for the rest of us. The only issue I have with agencies or booking agencies, on this topic, is for not pursuing a little more due diligence. A simple check of the files embedded information, would at least validate the timeline of the picture. Although I have never had any of my pics Photo Shopped, If I showed up to the cabana staff position today with a pic I took 5 years ago, I'd be sent home with my tail between my legs. [caption id="attachment_1721" align="alignright" width="160"] 5 years ago[/caption] But what about "touch-ups'? For high-profile events, where sex appeal and size are priority one, time-stamping is the ONLY tool agencies have to combat these practices. Outside of those exclusive and discriminating opportunities, time-stamping is downright overkill. By now you're probably saying to yourself, "I dunno Robert". "Sounds like alot of bashing." "Something you promised you wouldn't do." And you'd be right. If I didn't offer a solution.

The Solution

For high-profile, sex appeal positions, we're gonna have to live with time-stamps. Live by the sword of these opportunities, it's only fair to die by them, if you don't measure up. As for your regular "just don't be ugly" opportunities, a 30 day stamp should be more than sufficient. Outside of the common sense changes I mentioned before, not much changes about our appearance over a 30 day period. Not even over 90 days. Don't agree? Here's proof. [su_custom_gallery source="media: 1724,1723" link="post" width="210" height="220"] Can you tell any differences between the two? As with all of our posts, we're committed to promoting discussions that bring about positive change. Let the discussion begin. Is time-stamping fair?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Time Stamped Photos. Is it Fair?
The Good Guys take a look into the practice of time stamped photos for submissions. Is it fair?
