item.title: CES 2016 Staffer's Guide
item.dc:creator: goodguyrobert
item.content:encoded:
(pre-release post) A new Good Guy format that will definitely get cleaned up after my CES training tonight. There's very helpful information  you'll be glad you had. Just put your luggage in the corner until I get back.
  It's that time of year again boys and girls. Las Vegas host the largest gathering of event talent from around the country for the annual CES show . For the electronics and gadget industry, there is no bigger stage. A make or break moment for many brands and product launches. Staff get excited about the show for many reasons. [su_list icon="icon: arrow-circle-o-right"]
    Why All The Buzz
  • Higher Pay Rates
  • Brand Prestige
  • Great Networking Channels
  • It's Vegas Baby!
[/su_list] The largest show in America's number fun city, we talk about what to expect and inside tips for CES.   Have a Plan &  Backup Plan [caption id="attachment_1777" align="alignright" width="321"] Planning ahead is your weapon against surprises.[/caption] Las Vegas experiences its highest volume visitors during CES. With the highest concentration at the convention center, the surrounding areas are also affected. All the rules for parking and any means of cost-effective transportation change. Having a plan and a backup will ensure you make it to your booking on time and ready to go. Also, make sure you know exactly where your footprint is. And use more than one reference point. The floor can look much different from training day to show day. Get The Money Up Front. Splitting a hotel or the cost of getting to Las Vegas? Get the agreed upon money ahead of time. If someone in your group is making arrangements, ask for a receipt of payment. And make sure your name is somewhere on the reservation as a guest. These quick tasks will allow you to maximize your down time if your work schedules are different. If there's a difference in social schedules, it also keep anyone from being locked out. [su_box title="Yes. It really happened."] A group who traveled together, had been dealt the drama card when one of the members didn't have all of their money. Counting on an egg that didn't hatch, the organizer got stuck paying for that person. To this day, they have yet to be repaid.[/su_box]   Pack A Lunch [caption id="attachment_1779" align="alignright" width="200"] Avoid lines and keep expenses down. Bring a lunch.[/caption] The foot traffic is non-stop. Soon as one interaction has concluded, another inquisitive attendee is immediately there to take their place. So making the most of your breaks is important. Your feet will thank you later if you give them even the shortest rest. The lines at concession food choices are insane. One would expect an amusement ride at the end for all the fanfare. Equally so are the prices. Bring a lunch and a few snacks to avoid spending your entire break in line and going broke. [caption id="attachment_1780" align="alignleft" width="305"] Stay focused.[/caption] Business or Pleasure? Gambling, world-class night clubs and 24/7 alcohol, debauchery & fun at every corner. However, having too much fun the night before can make for a torturously long next event day. You will pay dearly on the floor for over indulging. The lights are bright, there's tons of noise, and no place to hide. Outside of a quick restroom  break, your  whereabouts will always be accounted for. In addition, the average cost per engagement doesn't get much more expensive than during these 4 days. As a result, execs will hold team leads and event managers accountable in monitoring the quality of these interactions. Not meeting those expectations, could get you sent packing. By keeping your commitment to the brand, the booking agency and your teammates as your main focus, good choices also become easy choices. Because Las Vegas is also commonly referred to as "Sin City", many sensible activity choices get lost in the neon. Having lived in Las Vegas for a long time, I assure you that there are many fun and sensible activities right on the strip. Bring a Spare Anything broken or not up to client specific requests will have to wait until the day is over. Spare pants, spare shoes, or spare attitude. Just keep in mind that storage space is usually reserved for the brand's 365 employees and execs. If you can't work without it, bring it, but keep it small. Somebody Is Always Watching With so many of the world's most successful brands and decision makers under the same roof, marketing firms make CES their "must go' event of the year. With higher expectations of the overall product and customer service, running into agency office people is not out of the ordinary. They may be dressed like anybody else attending or perhaps wearing branded gear. Be mindful when they are present will keep you from doing the wrong thing at the wrong time. For example, handing out your own personal business card on the floor.   Yeah, it'd be great to make a lasting impression on the agencies that book us. But what's often overlooked and  undervalued are the impressions you leave with your fellow colleagues. For veterans, it's a great time to put the rest of the body to the face of their social profile pics. For newbies, CES is a great resume builder. What's also valuable is working side by side with some of the most  polished and knowledgeable minds of our profession. [caption id="attachment_1781" align="alignright" width="182"] Not booked yet? Hawk social media until you are.[/caption]   The Red Headed Fat Kid We've all been there. Including yours truly. You didn't get picked to work CES. Don't worry Cinderella, if you really want to work CES, you can still make it to the ball. The fairy godmother will be played by your ready to serve laptop or mobile device. Submissions that are straight-forward and concise, with up to date images will be your carriage. Don't even consider attaching pics of yourself that are outdated or inaccurate. You'll be called out on it and sent back immediately. Pay close attention to the marketing sub menu under the jobs label and all relevant sub menus under the gigs label on Las Vegas Craigslist. Popular FaceBook pages like Brand Ambassadors of Las Vegas and the CES Promo Talent page are also great places to scour. These are closed groups so make sure to be added before the admins become unavailable. When an emergency last-minute staffing need occurs, these spots will appear here directly or indirectly. See an emergency booking post, don't wait to submit. Do it now. Right now! It's not always the most qualified or more experienced person that gets booked, but the quickest to submit and answer their phone. Be Aware of Your Surroundings CES has such an impact on the City of Las Vegas, economically and logistically, that everyone knows when the circus is coming to town. Unfortunately, the arrival of CES is also a great time for the underbelly of our beautiful city. [caption id="attachment_1787" align="alignright" width="268"] Staying close to the strip and all of their security, reduces your exposure to crime.[/caption] Las Vegas takes the safety and security of our visitors very seriously. Additional technology and human resources are added for CES. However,it's everyone's responsibility to be aware of the potential dangers. Don't venture too far away from the strip, especially at night. And be extremely cautious about inviting strangers up to your room. Don't be fooled into thinking that hotel crimes are gender specific. Men are equally victims of hotel crimes as women. If you're sharing accommodations, it's not a bad ideal to set some ground rules for these types of situations. Sharing respect for each others property and safety is always a good thing. Post CES The booking agent is happy. It's a wrap right? Wrong! How you wrap up this experience is equally important as how you performed during. After the dust settles and everyone has gone home, events are evaluated. Remember, brands invest more in this event than any other event on their corporate calendar. Just like the day after the Super Bowl, the winners and losers both look at the tape. What they see or don't see could ruin all your effort, professionalism and hard work. If you've gone this far, don't let a few common mistakes take away from the most important brand at CES. Yours. Social media traffic is off the charts after huge events like this. Eyes are everywhere. Right or wrong, positive or negative, people are forming an opinion. Be careful what you post. Read the Fine print Want your check on time? Double check your paperwork. Countless times agencies are bashed for paycheck related issues only to find out that the information provided was outdated or incorrect. Not reading the "terms of payment" section within the agency's contract is also another mistake. If in fact it is the agency's error, allow them an opportunity to rectify the problem within a reasonable time frame.
